column8: The gender test; Life put into perspective
column9: Investigates the increasingly popular practice amongst parents to have antenatal ultrasound scanning to ascertain the gender of their unborn child. Talks to several mothers about their experiences, including  situations where the scan incorrectly indicated the gender of their children, and to a mother who prefers not to know her child's gender until it is born. Talks to radiographer Diane Somerville and sonographer Karen Lissington of Hamilton Radiology about the technology they use to determine gender. Seeks comment from University of Waikato psychology professor Jane Ritchie about whether parents are placing gender expectations on babies before they are born. Talks to the mother who was in the midst of giving birth to her daughter during the 4 Sep 2010 earthquake in Canterbury.

Notes the recent payout to South Canterbury Finance (SFC) investors by the government deposit guarantee scheme. Provides Standard & Poor's Rating Services view on the financial impact of the earthquake.

Quake turmoil for anxious migrants

column8: The toll of leading a city's recovery
column9: Speaks to the Christchurch mayor about his personal and practical response to the Darfield earthquake. Evaluates his odds in the upcoming mayoral election and conveys his changed attitude to politics.

States how a city rebuilds its lost architecture, whether through war or natural disaster, is vital for its future. Compares what happened post-World War II in Europe where the author notes 'citizens of the city were comforted by a return of an architecture they knew and felt affection for' and what NZ's approach has been to the past. Recounts the rebuilding of Napier after the 1931 earthquake was constrained by the desire of the public wanting very strong buildings (reinforced concrete) and without high parapets. Designers had the example of Santa Barbara in California, which was rebuilt after a disastrous earthquake in 1925. Suggest Christchurch is entirely different, noting the destruction is in pockets and both historic and contemporary buildings have been damaged. Asks the question how will these Victorian and Edwardian buildings be rebuilt and asserts that Christchurch should.

Outlines the Chapman Tripp response to Parliament's passing of the Canterbury Earthquake Response and Recovery Act (CERRA), focusing on the Acts three mechanisms: the Recovery Commission, Orders in Council, and protections from liability for certain acts or omissions. Cautions that implementation of the Act be monitored, given its significant and unusual powers.

Ponders the legal consequences for post-earthquake Christchurch residents taking action regarding their property in the face of aftershocks, civil defence emergency requirements, heritage building issues, and other property complications. Questions the effectiveness of Canterbury Earthquake Response and Recovery Act (CERRA), and compares it to previous cover-all legislation, the Public Safety Conservation Act 1932 (PSCA).

column8: Traumatised Gran quits one quake zone for another
column9: Traumatised Gran quits one quake zone for another

Focuses on the likely effects of the 4 Sep 2010 earthquake on future building design. Talks to civil engineer John Hare, NZ Institute of Architects chairman Jasper van der Lingen and University of Canterbury professor of civil engineering professor Andy Buchanan about earthquake design over the years and lessons learnt from past major earthquakes and the most recent one.

Talks to architect Ian Athfield about the opportunity to reinvent Christchurch offered by the Canterbury earthquake. Looks at the pattern of destruction left by the quake, different from that of the 1931 Napier earthquake, and gives Athfield's comments on developing inner-city living, fitting new buildings in among the old, and how buildings and people interact. Discusses the earthquake strengthening work of earthquake engineers which helped save many old buildings, and the economic effects on businesses of the damage. Examines the problems in some Christchurch suburbs affected by liquefaction of the land.

Examines progress toward rebuilding the region, six weeks after the magnitude 7.1 earthquake. Seeks comment from spokespersons from the insurance and construction sectors and from the Earthquake Commission (EQC).

Revisits the 5.6 earthquake that shook Newcastle, Australia, on 28 December 1989, teasing out lessons for  post-quake Christchurch. Gleans information about the opportunities for urban renewal and civic building, the dangers of demolishing and rebuilding too soon, the pitfalls in moving from disaster to recovery, and the juncture of when to remember and forget the event. Cites advice by Australian consultant Brian Eastoe on how to coordinate post-quake interests to avoid disputes. Ponders Newcastle's unreadiness, given the area's history of tremors every 60 to 70 years. Chronicles the saving from demolition of the Christ Church Cathedral by architect Barney Collins, detailing the preservation technology utilised.

Examines the future of the Green Party now that Keith Locke is the only remaining original member. Discusses the new co-leadership of Russel Norman and Metiria Turei. Notes the party's stability compared to other minority parties. Profiles Young Greens co-leader Holly Walker. Indicates dissent over the Christchurch (Darfield) earthquake vote, and asks whether this shows a trend toward pragmatism over principles.  Talks to current and former Party members about whether there is a trend toward diversification versus activism. Ponders how the party will position itself at the next election, and whether the party policies are becoming mainstream.

column8: What lies beneath; What lies broken beneath
column9: Investigates the unseen damage to sewers in the city as a result of the 4 Sep earthquake. Talks to residents regarding the impact of the damage in their neighbourhoods and to Christchurch City Council water and waste unit manager Mark Christison about the preparations required to undertake repairs.

column8: What treasure lies under the quake rubble?
column9: Talks to the professional conservator and archaeologist about the opportunity created by the 4 Sep 2010 earthquake to explore the rubble underneath historic buildings. Discusses her past experience working at British sites for the British television programme 'Time Team', and informs that an approach is being made for funding for a similar programme in NZ to explore sites under damaged Christchurch buildings. Speaks to Frank van der Heijden, Canterbury and West Coast regional archaeologist for the Historic Places Trust, about the history of the city and its stance on old buildings damaged by the earthquake.

Talks to the Christchurch-born comedian about his memories of working with the late comedian, which he has captured in the release of a new DVD. Informs that he will perform at the Christchurch Art Gallery, 27 Nov 2010, to raise money for the earthquake relief fund.

Reflects on the response of the Government, aid agencies and counselling services in the wake of the Canterbury's earthquake to offer counselling to Cantabrians. Asks whether counselling is needed after a disaster without loss of life. Suggests of more value is social support and practical assistance. Reports the best form of support was the restoring of power and telecommunications, assisting with insurance claims and resolving water and sanitation issues. Indicates the need to watch out for those who may need counselling rather than making a blanket assumption about the need for counselling for all.

Talks about the case of a tradesman in Christchurch who cannot continue fixing earthquake-damaged chimneys and roofs because he is owed more than $160,000 for the work he has already completed. Suggestions what the tradesman did wrong.

column8: Standing up for heritage; Aussie architects view quake damage
column9: Meets South Dakotan Donovan Rypkema, an advocate for heritage buildings and their place in the 21st century. Talks to Australian heritage architects Barney Collis and Edward Clode, who visited the city recently to advise on what to do about heritage buildings that were damaged in the 4 Sep 2010 earthquake, and to learn about how to prepare for the next earthquake in Newcastle.
Talks to the architect who is part of a group working with  Wellington architect Ian Athfield to rebuild Christchurch following the earthquake. Explores his style, and lists some of his design tips.

Examines the future of the Green Party now that Keith Locke is the only remaining original member. Discusses the new co-leadership of Russel Norman and Metiria Turei. Notes the party's stability compared to other minority parties. Profiles Young Greens co-leader Holly Walker. Indicates dissent over the Christchurch (Darfield) earthquake vote, and asks whether this shows a trend toward pragmatism over principles.  Talks to current and former Party members about whether there is a trend toward diversification versus activism. Ponders how the party will position itself at the next election, and whether the party policies are becoming mainstream.

Reflects on the events of the year, dominated by the Christchurch earthquake and the Pike River mining explosion. Touches on overseas visitors to NZ (Hillary Clinton, Justin Bieber), the industrial dispute surrounding  the filming of The Hobbit, public service scandals, private fraudsters, sporting achievements, and a setting straight of the life of one of the miners killed at Pike River.
Quake-rattled chickens lay again
Shaken quake refugee plans return

column8: Family move from tsunami to bombs, quake and floods
column9: Family move from tsunami to bombs, quake and floods

Queries who is leading the rebuilding effort of quake-damaged Canterbury. Wonders whether the effort is being driven by bureaucracy, or whether the complex behind-the-scenes process is the right path for a complicated problem. Talks to former Christchurch mayor Garry Moore, Christchurch East MP Lianne Dalziel, Christchurch mayor Bob Parker and Christchurch City Council chief executive Tony Marryatt and Minister of Earthquake Recovery Gerry Brownlee. Includes a graphic showing the agencies involved in the rebuilding of the region.

column8: 'I was lucky' says worst-hit quake victim
column9: 'I was lucky' says worst-hit quake victim

Focuses on the residents of Seabreeze Close in Christchurch, who continue to live like refugees in ruined homes a full five months after the Canterbury earthquake liquified their street. Stresses the growing anger at the lack of action over thier plight.
Reports on the efforts to save and restore some of Fendalton's beautiful character homes, which were hard hit bt the Canterbury earthquake.

Recaps some of the most pressing problems facing Cantabrians and those charged with rebuilding the region after the major earthquake on 4 Sep 2010. Includes a timetable of meetings and other important events scheduled between 2011 and 2013. Touches on major rebuilding work under way. Reports on the demolition of the century-old Coptic Church. Overviews repair work to schools that has been completed or still to be done. Informs that a street barrier in Christchurch has been extended for public safety.

column8: Help in time of need for earthquake's victims
column9: Help in time of need for earthquake's victims

Reports in the wake of the September 2010 Christchurch earthquake Dunedin is taking a look at their own heritage buildings and how much they might lose if they were to experience a significant earthquake. Takes stock of the number of Historic Places Trust category one buildings, how many of those are earthquake strengthened, the number of heritage visitors that come to Dunedin and the economic benefit that brings. Assesses the likelihood of an earthquake in Dunedin considering the location of fault lines in the area and what the city has experienced so far. Comments on the current policy of Dunedin City Council with regard to earthquake strengthening of buildings.

column8: Aftershock adding to main quake damage
column9: Aftershock adding to main quake damage

column8: A helping hand leads to death for man on the way home
column9: Tells of Owen Wright, one of many who passed away while trying to help others in the Christchurch earthquake.

column8: Quiet hero becomes a Facebook sensation
column9: Tells of one of the heroes of the Christchurch earthquake.

Tells of the 12 suburbs in Christchurch surrounding Lyttelton and what affects the Christchurch earthquake has caused these towns. Suburbs include; Papanui, Avonhead, Yaldhurst, Sockburn, Templeton, Opawa, Shirley, Burwood, Southshore and Sumner.

Covers the effects of the devastating 6.3 magnitude earthquake, which has caused irrevocable damage and killed a substantial number of people, principally in the Central Business District. Ask why, concentrating on the CBD, did so many major buildings fall so catastrophically. Briefly profiles some of the stories of those who had close calls in the earthquake, and considers what long-lasting effects the ruination of Christchurch city will have on its residents.

Covers the effects of the devastating 6.3 magnitude earthquake, which has caused irrevocable damage and killed a substantial number of people, principally in the Central Business District. Asks why, concentrating on the CBD, did so many major buildings fall so catastrophically. Briefly profiles some of the stories of those who had close calls in the earthquake, and considers what long-lasting effects the ruination of Christchurch city will have on its residents.

Looks at where the money is going to come from to fix Christchurch and how this will affect what happens. Suggests that taxpayers may question the policy of guaranteeing to restore the ground, asking instead whether to simply accept that some places are too unstable to be built on. Considers this in light of the Earthquake Commission being the only major insurer in the world to insure the ground beneath buildings affected by an earthquake.

Offers advice about the preservation of Dunedin's old buildings, discussing who should do it and who should pay for it.  Notes that the topic of heritage buildings has beome timely in the wake of the Christchurch earthquake (September 4 2010) and the unassisted collapse of the part of the Barron Building in Rattray Street. Recaps Dunedin's record of destroying and preserving its historic buildings. Touches on the deficit in the recording of heritage buildings, mentioning the role of the Historic Places Trust.
Tells of the Christchurch Cathedral collapsing under the earthquake, but has the hopes of locals and those who grew up in Canterbury to rebuild and restore the Cathedral.

column8: Seconds to flee as six floors fall
column9: Talks with Mary-Anne Jackson, one of the survivors working in the CTV building that collapsed in the Christchurch earthquake and took most of her colleagues.

column8: The city was the colour of death
column9: Gives authors account of the Christchurch earthquake.
Gives authors recount of the day of the Christchurch earthquake (Feb 22 2011).
Recounts the author's experience of watching news coverage of the earthquake via live internet streaming while living in Berlin.

column8: Uncle Bob, he's the everywhere mayor
column9: Looks at the actions of the Christchurch mayor before and after the Feb 2011 earthquake, noting praise and criticism from NZers. Evaluates the effect of his work as a television host.  Touches on the earthquake's role in the city's mayoral race of 2010.

column8: Quake wake-up call for disaster insurer
column9: Looks at the impact the Canterbury/Christchurch earthquakes may have on the Earthquake Commission (EQC) and its ability to insure future natural disasters.
Reviews performances in the Last Night of the Proms, 25 Feb 2011, Dunedin Town Hall, including a piece by Mayor Dave Cull and songs sung in recognition of the Feb 22 Christchurch earthquake.

column8: Art deco crowds respond to quake
column9: Reports on the 11th Art Deco festival, held in Ranfurly Feb 2011, noting the special fundraising events held to assist people affected by the Christchurch earthquake.

Reports on plans to reprint the title by the Caitlin-based author that describes a cat's experience of an earthquake and is aimed at raising funds for the September 4 2010 and now the February 22 2011 earthquakes in the Christchurch region.

Comments on inevitable emotional outbursts by public figures following the earthquake. Posits homelessness as the major issue facing the Government, recapping the cover provided by most house insurance policies. Describes the process that must be followed before insurance companies can make payouts. Notes the unusual step that the Government may take regarding post-earthquake land restoration. Warns of the difficulty of governmental plans to spur growth while meeting the needs of people in Canterbury.

Shares her experience of the earthquake and seeing the destruction of and around her home of 17 years. Visits the CBD and other parts of the city reporting on the sights and smells of post-earthquake Christchurch, including the good and humorous things that are also happening. Relays the issues of rebuilding, unemployment, and the possible lack of doctors to care for crush victims. Looks to the need for a sensible vision for the city for those who are destined to stay there.

Discusses the debate on heritage versus safety in NZ, in the wake of buildings crumbling in the Canterbury earthquakes. Indicates how older and more recently built structures fared in the Feb 22 earthquake, including the Pyne Gould building and the ChristChurch Cathedral. Examines the purpose of earthquake strengthening and the requirements of the 2004 Building Act. Notes the safety status of post-earthquake buildings in Napier. Laments the cautiousness of authorities regarding earthquake-prone buildings. Speaks to councillors and heritage experts about the building code strength of structures in Wellington. Notes the number of unreinforced masonry buildings in NZ. Cites heritage specialists regarding the tradeoff between saftey, cost and heritage.

Talks to University of British Columbia geography professor David Edgington about his research into reconstruction following the 1995 earthquake in Kobe, Japan, highlighting contrasts with and lessons for Christchurch. Advises of the need for speed and to provide long-term confidence for private sector rebuilding.  [Print exclusive]

column8: Strength to lead city in the eye of a storm
column9: Talks to the Christchurch mayoress about the response of the mayoral couple to the devastating earthquake.

column8: Help from all directions [part 1]; Mayor to hold public meetings
column9: Focuses on the effects of the earthquake on residents and businesses in the eastern suburbs. Informs that Mayor Bob Parker will address four open-air meeting in various parts of the eastern suburbs, 6 Mar 2011.

column8: Strength born of adversity and faith
column9: Showcases the work being done by four of the front-line staff who are coordinating the relief and recovery operation and preparing the city to move forward after the devastating earthquake. Speaks to Christchurch City Council operations manager Peter McDonald, emergency operations centre manager Murray Sinclair, Christchurch City Council building evaluation manager Steve McCarthy and welfare team member Annette Purvis.

Concentrates on how grassroots organisations are beginning to make their presence felt in post-earthquake Christchurch. Talks to various community organisers about the potential for a grassroots approach to change the nature of local politics and community decision making.

column8: Simple steps to heal the mental scars
column9: Offers advice to assist Cantabrians to recover from the psychological damage of the earthquakes. Seeks comment from Cerina Altenburg, team leader of the General Practice Mental Health Liaison Service, Christchurch.

column8: How to mend a shattered city from the ground up
column9: Considers some of the factors to be taken into account when planning the reconstruction of Christchurch city, including being cautious about multi-storey buildings. Asserts that the experts need to understand why some areas and structures were harder hit than others. Looks at the issues that will form the basis of expert consideration on Christchurch's future, including siesmic gaps, lifelines, liquefaction and slips. Touches on domestic and commercial building types that fared better during the quake.

column8: Interpreter's magic hands speak to thousands
column9: Praises the directive to have news coverage of the Christchurch earthquake translated into sign language, NZ's third official language. Extols the talents of Jeremy Borland, who has done much of the interpreting during television news items.

Asserts that people who do not wish to remain in the city after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake should have the option to do so. Comments on the challenges of rebuilding homes and remediating property and the policy approach that Government, the Christchurch City Council and the Earthquake Commission (EQC) should be taking to address these challenges.

column8: All Kiwis counting the cost of quake with bigger premiums
column9: Focuses on the role of insurance companies in rebuilding the commercial heart of the city and its residential suburbs after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Seeks comment from Chris Ryan, chief executive of the Insurance Council, and others. Provides facts about the role and functions of the commission.

Interviews six-year-old twins Grace Newman and Thomas Newman, sisters Lauren Sargent and Anna Sargent and brothers Timothy Cornell and Benjamin Cornell about their experiences of the earthquake, which struck while all were at school.

column8: With a little help from our friends
column9: Focuses on the residents of the eastern suburbs of Christchurch and what they are doing to help each other and the help that has arrived to improve their living conditions after the Christchurch February earthquake amongst which are lack of electricity, water, toilets and the problems associated with flooding and liquefaction.

column8: Rebuilding Brand NZ; Urgent task to rebuild Brand NZ
column9: Reports on the stress felt by the tourism industryas it tries to combat the inevitable negative effects of the Christchurch earthquake on tourism in NZ in the short term.

Talks to the Christchurch-raised musician about being apart from the Christchurch-based members of his family on the day of the earthquake. Discusses the process of making his new album, to be released at the Homegrown music festival, Wellington, 5 Mar 2011.
Offers advice for coping at home in post-quake Christchurch, where potable water is scarce and toilets may be located outdoors.

column8: Home will never be home again; Homes away from home
column9: Looks at some people who have moved to another location outside Christchurch after experiencing the second earthquake in February 2011 and have decided not to return to Christchurch to live. Gauges the effect of this move, whether permanent or temporary on South Island towns who are accommodating the influx of people. Notes the short term influx of people is stretching housing, education, health and welfare services.

column8: Influx of earthquakes refugees tests Timaru's resources
column9: Reports that Timaru's population has swelled by 20%, from 27,000 to 33,000 with a flood of 6,000 Christchurch residents getting out of their shaken city. Questions how long will these people stay indicating it makes it difficult to plan in terms of school rolls, housing/accommodation and infrastructure.

Examines the gamut of emotional, behavioural, physical and cognitive responses to emergency situations such as the 22 February earthquake, including the author's own experience as an Aucklander and ex-Christchurch resident. Provides advice from Auckland University associate professor of clinical psychology Ian Lambie.

column8: Quake rebuilding costs a big stretch in tough times
column9: Considers how NZ will pay for the reconstruction of Christchurch when the estimated cost is $20 billion, particularly in hard financial times. Looks at forecasts from NZIER (New Zealand Institute of Economic Research) which indicate 'virtually no economic growth' and the closing of NZers wallets' to reduce debt. Forecasts higher costs for individuals and businesses along with a spike in unemployment. Notes in the short term there will be an injection of cash into the economy with money being released by EQC (Earthquake Commission) and overseas insurers along with an expected cut in the OCR (official cash rate) by 25 basis points. Includes an outline of where the author thinks the money is coming from and who is paying.

Examines the issue of whether to turn Christchurch CBD into a flat, structureless green park and the businesses moved elsewhere. Notes in the last 200 years or so it has been rare for central governments to let their cities die. Discusses factors such as building practices, rebuilding of heritage buildings, stability of the ground and the materials that will be used if the decision is to reconstruct Christchurch. Includes the evolution of building standards.

column8: Quake set to hit premiums; Scale of destruction means many will suffer because of long rebuild time
column9: Examines the issue of insurance and earthquakes and the financial consequences for insurance companies and their reinsurers that have arisen as a result of the two catastrophic earthquakes that have severely damaged Christchurch and parts of Canterbury. Notes Chris Ryan (Insurance Council chief executive) is of the view that because reinsurance makes up a large part of insurance companies' costs he expects the increases in reinsurance prices will be passed on to customers through higher premiums. Notes the issue of people and corporations who are under insured and the consequences of having to wait a long time for houses and business premises to be rebuilt.

Examines the safety of Auckland buildings in the wake of the recent earthquake in Christchurch. Notifies of delays in risk assessment due to the super city amalgamation. Outlines the city's Earthquake Prone Buildings Policy. Compares the differing building policies of councils depending on the earthquake risk of the area they control. Notes the number of buildings considered by Auckland City Council to be at risk.

Assesses the current economic situation, given the likelihood of a 'double-dip' recession, the Pike River Mine and Christchurch earthquakes disasters and other economic factors. Seeks comment from several economists and economic analysts about whether the economy is improving or getting worse.

column8: Earthquake law - the debate continues; Earthquake update
column9: Comments further on the current law being used to deal with the effects of the earthquake on 4 Sep 2010. Cites concern expressed by the Auckland District Law Society and other lawyers that the powers granted in the Act (CERRA) go further than any previous legislation, including the Public Safety Conservation Act 1932. Includes an update noting that this column was written before the more destructive earthquake of 22 Feb 2011.

column8: [Secondary scene : East Otago High School]; Martinborough moods a feast for the senses; Christchurch casualties not forgotten; A dark day
column9: Features creative writing and art from four East Otago High School pupils, including observations of a visit to Martinborough, a report and a poem on the Christchurch earthquake, and artwork by Sarah Law about her holiday from Dunback to Wellington in early 2010.

Profiles six people who have key roles in the aftermath of the earthquake. Talks to the coroner, the chief executive of energy company Orion NZ Ltd, the NZ Police Superintendent and night commander, the director of special operations for the Fire Service, the Civil Defence national controller and the Labour MP for Christchurch Central.

column8: Broad shoulders to carry city forward
column9: Profiles six people who have key roles in the aftermath of the earthquake. Talks to the coroner, the chief executive of energy company Orion NZ Ltd, the NZ Police Superintendent and night commander, the director of special operations for the Fire Service, the Civil Defence national controller and the Labour MP for Christchurch Central.

column8: Shuddering in Wellington; The Cuba St Quarter
column9: Focuses on the concern surrounding the city's earthquake-prone buildings in light of the deadly 22 February 2011 Christchurch Earthquake. Talks to Wellington Mayor Celia Wade-Brown about the restrengthening timeframes for the city's earthquake-prone buildings. Looks at what makes a building earthquake-prone and what buildings are required to withstand. Presents a map of the earthquake-prone buildings in the Cuba Street area.

column8: Health service ready to help mentally scarred
column9: Reports that health professionals in the region are preparing for an influx of people who will need help to cope with the trauma of the earthquakes. Seeks comment from Prof Mark Creamer, director of the Australian Centre for Post-Traumatic Mental Health, about the range of responses people have to disastrous events, and the importance of having fun to improve wellbeing. Cites remarks from Canterbury District Health Board chief of psychiatry Sue Nightingale. Talks to some people who survived the earthquake about how they are faring. Speaks to pharmacist Don Sache about the increase in demand for tranquillisers or sleeping pills.

column8: What's next?; Ring predictions play on fears
column9: Asks earthquake experts for their assessment of whether a third big earthquake is likely, particularly given the existence of a previously hidden fault that ruptured on 26 Dec 2010, causing a magnitude 4.9 earthquake that caused significant damage to or weakening of buildings in the central business district. Notes the ethical and political difficulties for scientists in determining what information to impart and when. Talks to GNS Science natural hazards manager Dr Kelvin Berryman, visiting Pennsylvania State University geologist Prof Kevin Furlong and University of Canterbury geological sciences Prof Jarg Pettinga. Cites comment from Christchurch Mayor Bob Parker about the need for a thorough survey of geological hazards before considering a multibillion-dollar rebuild. Asks some of these people to comment on the prediction by Auckland weather forecaster Ken Ring of another major earthquake in the region on 20 Mar 2011.

Comments on the lessons that should be learned in rebuilding the central business district (CBD) of the city following the latest large earthquake on 22 Feb 2011. Recalls a reprint of an old colonial drawing showing the  landscape of the Canterbury Plains in the early 1850s, depicting low-lying swampland that later became the CBD. Notes that the areas worst affected by the earthquake are located in these old marshes. Offers advice to town planners in the city. Cautions that Hamilton and Whanganui also have similar landscapes so building codes should be updated.

Showcases the visual-simulation specialist firm that is continuing to hire staff despite having to abandon its leased premises in the cordoned-off section of the central business district after the 22 Sep 2011 earthquake. Talks to company founder Sam Chaffey about its business activities in NZ and overseas.

column8: Jo flees NZ quake for ordeal in Japan
column9: Jo flees NZ quake for ordeal in Japan

Follows the plight of Bexley residents in Seabreeze Close since September, the time of the first major earthquake to hit Christchurch. Reports they continue to live like refugees in ruined homes a full five months after the Canterbury earthquake liquified their street. Stresses the growing anger at the lack of action over thier plight.

column8: Christchurch 2016; Beginner's guide to rebuilding; Welcome to our Christchurch; Voices from abroad
column9: Looks at how Christchurch city is going to rebuild and recounts what happen in the case of Napier after the 1931 earthquake flattened the city. Notes the debate about the realities of knocking down buildings, whether repair is possible for some heritage buildings is growing and a decision about whether to build high or low also has to be made. Features comment from Norman Foster (British architect), Hank Dittmar (chief executive of Prince Charles's conservation minded Foundation for the Built Environment) and Simon Jenkins (UK journalist). Includes interviews of ten prominent NZers who give a wide range of personal views about what shape the city of Christchurch should take.

Portrays life in Christchurch two weeks after the big quake hit it. Shows residents such as Brian Frisken (74, Bexley) and Barbara Kerr (Aranui) coping with living in the aftermath, and describes community support and efforts to recover. Discusses the problem of temporary housing with winter approaching.

Discusses the state of earthquake prediction.  Looks at a Geonet model used by Matt Gerstenberger of GNS Science to show earthquake and aftershock probabilities in Canterbury, describing their use in wake of the recent pair of earthquakes and the possibility of the Alpine Fault triggering an even larger earthquake. Looks at the possible use of warning time given by an early warning system.
Discusses the pitfalls of the idea of 'GDP' (gross domestic product), looking at the effects of the Christchurch earthquake as an example.
Gives a personal account of being caught up in the earthquake in Christchurch while being involved with the Ellerslie Flower Show. Draws inspiration from Christchurch's image as a garden city.

Talks to Lisa Blatchford, bassist and vocalist for the Auckland-based trio that started in Christchurch as 'Starlett'. Backgrounds the work that has gone into their debut album, recorded in Los Angeles. Mentions what happened to her family after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake.

column8: Skilled in action; Firms look overseas amid looming skills shortage
column9: Looks at the current skills shortage in NZ and what is being done to address it. Talks to the former world champion discus thrower, now the chief executive of Best Pasifika Leadership Academy, about her own  upskilling plan and the focus of the Academy. Seeks comment from others in the building, engineering, hospitality and IT sectors, as well as spokespersons from the recruitment and industry training sectors and ANZ chief economist Cameron Bagrie. Informs that construction and infrastructure firms are likely to form alliances with international companies to provide the skilled labour necessary to rebuild Christchurch.

Speaks to two families who have been displaced by the Christchurch earthquake about their plans for the future. Notes that the region has 'quietly absorbed' hundreds, and possibly thousands, of Christchurch residents, some of whom are likely to remain in Otago.

column8: City unites on day of healing
column9: Describes the service held in Hagley Park in memory of the February 22 2011 earthquake, featuring parts of speeches given by Mayor Bob Parker, Ngai Tahu elder Henare Rakiihia, and Prince William. Relays the experience of some of the families of those killed in the earthquake.

Explores the options being considered for rebuilding Christchurch after its two earthquakes. Describes the damage, the most prominent weaknesses, and restoration efforts, as they relate to the city's affected suburbs, hills, and CBD area. Raises questions about the destruction, restoration or rebuilding of heritage and central city buildings. Quotes the views of Compusoft Engineering director Barry Davidson on seismic engineering, lack of political will to enforce building standards, and the need to check engineer's designs. Illustrates a model of a resilient house designed by Copeland Associates Architects.

column8: The rise of the cake-stall nation
column9: Talks to the head of the Christchurch Earthquake Appeal Mark Weldon about the funds raised so far. Touches on the effect of the earthquake and tsunami in Japan.  Names the three main funds to which people can contribute, and outlines what the money is being spent on.

Profiles the CEO of Orion about his role in restoring electricity to Christchurch after its earthquakes. Talks about his hero status in the city and his career in the electricity sector. Touches on his salary, famous family members and why he is an energy-conscious person.
Provides a diary of his days following the earthquake, starting at the Goodbye Blue Monday live music venue in Christchurch that he co-owns with his parents and siblings.

column8: Interim 'villages' of units planned; Logistics of rehousing Christchurch will be daunting
column9: Examines the tender document proposal from the Dept of Building and Housing for 'imminent' temporary accommodation in the city following the two earthquakes. Describes the three stages being assessed. Talks to Dunedin builders and Dunedin City Council economic development manager Peter Harris about the logistical difficulties of housing displaced Christchurch residents.

Focuses on the prediction by Auckland weather forecaster Ken Ring that Christchurch would experience another large earthquake on 20 Mar 2011. Talks to him about public reaction to his prediction, including death threats. Seeks comment from ACC Minister Nick Smith and several scientists who refute his methods and dismiss his predictions as misguided and irresponsible. Speaks to Victoria University psychologist Assoc Prof Marc Wilson about the results of his 2008 study into beliefs. Includes other tried but unproven ways of predicting the future.
Talks to local residents in Christchurch and Lyttelton to see how they are faring after the second major earthquake since 4 Sep 2010. Sums up the situation.
Looks at ways in which Christchurch can help pay its share of the bill for the February 22 earthquake.

column8: What Napier can teach Christchurch about rebuilding; Need for haste balanced with the need for preservation
column9: Focuses on three lessons that Christchurch can learn from Napier, which recovered quickly after their city was ruined in a 7.9 magnitude earthquake, 3 Feb 1931. Cites an 1997 paper by economist Simon Chapple, estimating the economic impact of the Napier quake. Seeks comment on this paper from NZ Institute of Economic Research principal economist Shamubeel Eaqub, who emphasises the relevance of these findings to Christchurch. Speaks to Hawke's Bay museum and art gallery programmes leader Eloise Taylor, curator of an exhibition on the rebuilding of Napier. Talks to the retired architect who lived through the Feb 1931 earthquake, who comments on the situation and the parallels between the cities.
Talks to the first winner of the Masterchef television cooking programme, Brett McGregor, about his experience of the Christchurch earthquakes and his first cookbook.

Portrays the frustration of Christchurch business owners whose CBD buildings have been barred by Civil Defence authorities, though journalists and dignitaries can participate in inner city guided tours. Talks to business owners - Gerald Westenra, David Collins, Joe Arts and Nicky Arts and Andrew Wheeley and Adele Wheeley - about how the ban has affected their businesses. Conveys criticism of and praise for the Canterbury Business Recovery service. Outlines plans for the central business district that are similar to those carried out in Napier after the 1931 earthquake.
Discusses the damaged caused to Christchurch after the Feb 2011 earthquake and estimates the cost to rebuild.

column8: Mum who lost family in quake wants to help
column9: Mum who lost family in quake wants to help

Looks at earthquake damage in Christchurch. Assesses potential future hazards and design principles, including ideas about precincts, low rise blocks, parks, land ownership, car parking and urban villages.  Reveals University of Canterbury Vice-Chancellor Rod Carr's suggestion for developing Christchurch central. Emphasises the need for consultation on masterplans for rebuilding. Presents a debate over ways to stimulate commercial activity in the CBD, focusing on rent levels.

Reflects on the role of writers in capturing memories of parts of the city that have been lost after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Sums up a Kim Hill with the Christchurch-born and -raised author about 'the solace of art and literature', referring to several books about the city and the poems 'Pause' and 'Response' by Mary Ursula Bethell. Describes other books that have their settings in Christchurch after a telephone conversation with the author.

Investigates the devastating impact of the 4 Sep 2010 and 22 Feb 2011 earthquakes on churches in the city, and the questions and challenges now faced by clergy and congregations.  Speaks to Anglican Bishop of Christchurch Victoria Matthews, The Rev Lynda Patterson, Catholic Bishop of Christchurch Barry Jones and The Rev Martin Stewart.

column8: Realism in the wake of the earthquake
column9: Suggests, now that most services are running again in Christchurch, it may be time to focus on  achievements made since the earthquakes. Considers the effects of not holding World Cup rugby games in the city. Notes the differing ways in which community links are severed.

Offers practical advice to Cantabrians on methods of getting the body back in balance to cope with the stress of the earthquakes and the constant aftershocks. Explains the role of adrenalin, serotonin, dopamine and endophins.

column8: Quake a tale of two cities for business; Message to business; How does the end of the subsidy affect your business?
column9: Reports on the status of businesses in the city as a result of the earthquake, based on a poll quoted this week by business leaders. Signals that the Government payroll and job loss subsidies package would be winding up. Lists key points made by Earthquake Recovery Minister Gerry Brownlee, Acting Minister of Economic Development David Carter, and Canterbury Employers Chamber of Commerce chief executive Peter Townsend. Talks to the owners of Switch Espresso, Pastel Shoe Dyers and Red Furniture about their situation.

column8: Skilled in action; Firms look overseas for skills
column9: Looks at the current skills shortage in NZ and what is being done to address it. Talks to the former world champion discus thrower Beatrice Faumuina, now the chief executive of Best Pasifika Leadership Academy, about her own upskilling plan and the focus of the Academy. Seeks comment from others in the building, engineering, hospitality and IT sectors, as well as spokespersons from the recruitment and industry training sectors and ANZ chief economist Cameron Bagrie. Informs that construction and infrastructure firms are likely to form alliances with international companies to provide the skilled labour necessary to rebuild Christchurch.

column8: Tragic face of quake to be laid to rest; Baker who predicted shake a 'great guy' - colleague
column9: Tragic face of quake to be laid to rest; Baker who predicted shake a 'great guy' - colleague

column8: Family lays 'face of the quake' to rest
column9: Family lays 'face of the quake' to rest

Talks to the historian, former journalist and communist who donated a Don Binney painting ('Kotare over the Ratana Church') to the Christchurch earthquake recovery, and which was subsequently actioned for $270,000, about his generosity and his writing.

Considers whether Auckland has been less supportive than other areas of appeals to assist Christchurch after the latest  earthquake. Talks to John Paul Moss about his failed attempt to organise a charity concert in Auckland. Seeks comment from Christchurch comedian Gary McCormick about his views on assistance given to the city.

Details the powers that the Cabinet has agreed to invest in the chief executive of Cera (Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority). Considers the effect of this relinquishing of control coming on the heels of the Government's sacking of Environment Canterbury in 2010.  Describes the development of an inner city earthquake recovery plan, led by the City Council, to which Christchurch residents will be able to contribute, as well a community forum, noting these fora will act as checks on Cera's power.

column8: A policy of no tears after calamity; Beware of cheap insurance policies without first checking for 'fishhooks'
column9: Investigates whether people can afford to be without insurance cover after the Christchurch earthquake. Talks to the Wairarapa woman whose rented house was destroyed by fire in 2006. Seeks views of Insurance Council chief executive Chris Ryan, Kapiti financial adviser Liz Koh, business development manager Terri Carrick and Insurance and Savings Ombudsman Karen Stevens. Discusses the relatively common practice among celebrities to insure body parts. Speaks to a specialist broker about the dearth of 'personal accident' insurance in NZ. Estimates 'multi-policy' insurance premiums for a hypothetical family of four living in Johnsonville.

Assesses the effect on the retail trade of the 22 Feb earthquake in Christchurch. Seeks comment from Retailers Association chief executive John Albertson on his outlook for the retail sector.  Celebrates the rise in prices enjoyed in the dairy, wool and lamb sectors, and anticipates benefits for retail and hospitality sectors associated with the Football World Cup starting on 9 Sept.

column8: Learning to live with loss of a limb
column9: Focuses on the relatively common procedure of limb amputation. Finds that every year nearly 400 people lose limbs, mainly because of vascular problems or diabetes. Talks about the physical and emotional impact of the loss on amputees with experts such as Karen Michalanney, a field officer for the Amputee Society of Wellington, and Philippa Williams, a physiotherapist at the Wellington Artificial Limb Centre. Speaks to double-amputee Ben Hekenui about how his life changed after losing his legs in a baling machine. Briefly explains how a lower leg is amputated. Mentions the case of Brian Coker who had both legs amputated to free him from rubble after the 22 February 2011 Christchurch earthquake.

Criticises the government's response to the Christchurch earthquakes. Alleges that the Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority demonstrates a good example of how not to run a recovery. Stresses the need for the organisation to be flexible, open and capable of engaging with local community leaders. Highlights the plight of residents in the badly-hit eastern suburbs, some of whom are still waiting for running water to be restored.

Asks the question 'Can he make the Christchurch Arts Festival work in 2011?' Having the experience of organising the Southern Lakes Festival of Colour for the past 15 years, Philip Tremewan, says 'Christchurch needs a festival now, more than ever'. Describes the option now facing the organisers with Christchurch being in an altered and damaged state after the September and February earthquakes. Indicates although the venues, final programme and timing will all remain up in the air, what seems certain is that Christchurch will have an arts festival in 2011.

column8: Quake refugees find haven in resort; Wanaka enchants Chch quake refugees
column9: Covers the role Wanaka has played in settling families displaced by the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake, noting the effects on the town's resources and schools. Gives statistics for post-earthquake enrolment of Christchurch pupils in schools nationwide. Describes the experience of the Fitzgerald and Hanson families and asks if they will return to Christchurch.

column8: Sam the man; Read all about it
column9: Talks to Sam Johnson, the motivating force behind the Student Volunteer Army. Gives his background, noting his early leadership talent. Shows how he kicked off a student volunteer clean-up following the first Christchurch earthquake, 4 Sep 2010, including the ad-hoc organisation needed to deal with unexpected numbers. Relates his standing for local politics, setting the Student Volunteer Army (SVA) up on Facebook, and his immediate reaction to the 22 Feb 2011 quake. Looks at how the SVA organised itself with IT and texting and handled a better management structure, and looks at him being recruited to help in Japan. Describes how the Hyde family of Redcliff created the 'Redcliff InfoPoint' social media and information service in the wake of the Feb 2011 earthquake to help their community.

Delves into the issue of whether land in suburbs damaged by the 22 February 2011 earthquake is worth rebuilding on. Describes the geotechnical work being undertaken, and what will happen when the information is reported in mid-May. Notes the complicating factor of increased flood risk in certain areas.  Talks to Canterbury University expert Misko Cubrinski about liquefaction and lateral spreading. Itemises the questions on land remediation facing the Government once the geotechnical report is complete.

Revisits Christchurch two months after the February earthquake and a number of people tell their story. Emma Howard and Chris Greenslade, Ray Rarere, Ian McLeod and Drina Sisarich, and Amo Perelini reveal how the earthquake affected them and what they have done since the 22nd February.

Talks to the following NZers about faith, prayer, God, and religion: physical sciences professor and NZer of the Year Sir Paul Callaghan, Little Bushman vocalist Warren Maxwell, real estate worker Lynley Webster, Wellington mayor Celia Wade-Brown, Catholic archbishop John Dew, track and field record holder Hamish Carson, Christchurch mayor Bob Parker, and office administrator Mary Denton.

column8: Many lessons learnt, says post-quake boss
column9: Learns the views of the Civil Defence national controller on his role and perceptions of his approach to the aftermath of the February 22 2011 earthquake in Christchurch. Covers his military career and how this background came to the fore in his control of the disaster. Shares lessons that other NZ councils and other countries could learn about disaster response.

Describes the journalist's experience of reporting from within Christchurch's cordoned off area at Civil Defence headquarters after the February 22 2011 earthquake. Touches on the media briefings at the Art Gallery, the international media, bus tours of the city centre, the visit by Prince William, and other impressions of the earthquake affected central business district.

column8: Quake chief bows out : 'I think I've done my bit'
column9: Learns the views of the Civil Defence national controller on his role and perceptions of his approach to the aftermath of the February 22 2011 earthquake in Christchurch. Covers his military career and how this background came to the fore in his control of the disaster. Shares lessons that other NZ councils and other countries could learn about disaster response.

Reports on Christchurch's continuing crisis post-earthquakes, emphasising vanishing jobs and massive skills shortages. Highlights how entire sectors, including the tourism and foreign education markets, are in free-fall, while the real estate market is barely alive. Talks about various projects being set up to rebuild the workforce in Christchurch, particularly in the construction industry.

Considers the abilities and qualities of the man in charge of the Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (CERA) and the $8 billion rebuild of Christchurch. Looks back on his family background, childhood and career. Touches on his vision for how many of the city's icon heritage buildings should be restored.

Talks to Conal McFeely, who runs Creggan Enterprises (a community economic development organisation in one of Londonderry's poorest suburbs), about how the rebuilding of strife-torn Londonderry can hold lessons for quake-ravished Christchurch.

Talks to Conal McFeely, who runs Creggan Enterprises (a community economic development organisation in one of Londonderry's poorest suburbs), about how the rebuilding of strife-torn Londonderry can hold lessons for quake-ravished Christchurch.

column8: How a quake-devastated community rebuilt itself; Rebuilding after the big one; Picking up and getting on with life [part 1]
column9: Visits the California town devastated by the 6.9 Loma Prieta earthquake, 17 Oct 1989. Accompanies representatives of the Canterbury Chamber of Commerce to learn about how the town recovered over time, and lessons for NZ in the aftermath of the Canterbury earthquakes. Talks to several members of the business community, including a man whose two workmates died in the rubble of their coffee roasting business, and to a man whose independent bookshop was tagged as unsafe but whose business was saved by volunteer community labour. Speaks to the city planner and city manager about the rebuilding process. Talks to construction magnate Barry Swenson, who developed properties in Santa Cruz and who owns properties in NZ, including the earthquake-damaged Red Lion Hotel, Rangiora. Tells the stories of two women who were injured in the Santa Cruz earthquake. Briefly compares the California and 22 Feb 2011 Christchurch earthquakes. Includes a redevelopment timeline for the Santa Cruz community from 1989-1995.

column8: Shot, home lost in quake but cop finds hope in hard times: six months after being attacked at a siege in Christchurch an officer has returned to work
column9: Shot, home lost in quake but cop finds hope in hard times: six months after being attacked at a siege in Christchurch an officer has returned to work

column8: Quake news too much for former journalist
column9: Quake news too much for former journalist

column8: Getting back to business after the big one
column9: Speaks to Gen-i South Island sales manager Paul Deavoll about the aftermath of the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake on his business and staff. Describes his role in helping to keep Christchurch online.

Investigates the complacency surrounding the earthquake risk-management of older, unreinforced masonry buildings and the difficult questions the Canterbury earthquakes have raised for communities and councils around the country. Speaks to a number of engineers and heritage advocates about the issue and the various options for councils. Focuses on the situation in Auckland. Talks to building owners about their reaction to an incomplete Auckland Council list of around 400 pre-1940s buildings in the old Auckland City area which desktop analysis suggests may be below the 33 per cent of the design level threshold a new building must achieve to withstand a moderate earthquake. Discusses the option of retrofitting to strengthen at-risk older buildings, which is also recommended for reinforced concrete structures built from the 1940s to 1976.

column8: High tech homing signal a godsend
column9: Reports that missing pets that are microchipped and registered with the National Companion Animal Register can be returned to owners faster, and more often than pets that are not chipped. Notes that 85 percent of chipped pets missing after the 22 February Christchurch earthquake were returned, compared with 20-25 percent of unchipped pets.

column8: A disaster's silver lining; Before complacency creeps in; Case study : bracing Berkeley; Liquefaction : when the ground turns to mush [part 3]
column9: Looks at how the 6.9 magnitude Loma Prieta earthquake that struck San Francisco in 1989 provided the city with an unexpected opportunity to transform its disused waterfront, which had been cut off from the city by the double-decker Embarcadero Freeway. Focuses on San Francisco's efforts to improve diaster preparedness after the earthquake. Speaks to building inspector Laurence Kronfield who pioneered the coloured tag building system that was used in Christchurch after the Canterbury earthquakes. Mentions some of the recommendations from the Building Inspection Department's 'Community Action Plan for Seismic Safety' (CAPSS), which was set up to rank the most dangerous buildings and formulate a plan to make them safer. Spotlights the University of California's earthquake-strengthening project at its Berkeley campus. Talks about the liquefaction that occurred in San Francisco's Marina district during the earthquake. Touches on some ground improvement techniques to limit liquefaction risks.

column8: Quake shakes foundations of couple's 28-year marriage
column9: Quake shakes foundations of couple's 28-year marriage

column8: Residents continue to tough it out but now they need some answers
column9: Looks at the situation of various families three months on from the Christchurch earthquake. Indicate they live in some of the worst hit areas in Christchurch, the eastern suburbs. Reports the residents are awaiting decisions from the Christchurch City Council and EQC (Earthquake Commission) with regard land and homes before they make firm decisions about their own plans. Notes what is working and what is not working in the eastern suburbs, how they are coping and what the residents want to happen next.

column8: Feeling the ache of infinite distance; Absconder
column9: Pays tribute to the late University of Otago graduate, former poetry contributor and newly qualified journalist, who perished in the CTV building in the Christchurch earthquake, 22 Feb 2011. Seeks comment from Dr Jacob Edmond and Dr Emma Neale about his contributions to the English Department at the university. Republishes a poem he wrote for the 'Monday's Poem' column, including some commentary from his mother, Fran Brookbanks.

column8: Columnist back in her home city with Old Bucky
column9: Tells of the moments immediately after the Christchurch earthquake (Old Bucky) and getting back to her own home to find it severely damaged. Reflects on living within the 'Red Zone' and on her decision to return to Christchurch to look after her ageing parents along with the force of nature.

column8: Shreds of life hang in red-stickered houses
column9: Notes many people are grieving at the loss of buildings, former old homes to the Christchurch earthquake.

Reports on aspects of the Budget presented by Government, 19 May 2011. Sums up changes to the KiwiSaver and Working for Families schemes. Touches on the new Earthquake Kiwi Bond to help fund rebuilding in Christchurch, a rise in infrastructure spending, increased funding for dementia care, health funding, sale of state assets and debt reduction. Overviews changes to the student loan scheme, and increased funding for domestic medical students, community law centres and early childhood education. Includes reaction from residents in the region and from national commentators.

column8: City's heritage another casualty of quake
column9: City's heritage another casualty of quake

Reflects on cultural clashes after the German born author returned from a book tour of Germany and talks about how the Christchurch earthquake influenced her mental attitude and state. Describes how she managed the book tour while having left her family and devastated home and the people of Christchurch and Lyttelton back in NZ.

Speaks to the two Los Angeles-based actors about being NZers overseas and why they are lending their support to the 22 May 'Rise up Christchurch' telethon to raise funds for the New Zealand Government's Christchurch Earthquake Appeal. Talks about their acting careers.

Tells the story of the first 90 days since the 2011 Christchurch earthquake, as experienced by a Port Hills community. Describes the use of the internet to exchange information, the forming of groups to fill hillside cracks with bentonite under the guidance of resident Mara Apse, and the enjoyment of a community tango

Talks to Shirley Boys' High School principal, John Laurenson, about his school's having to relocate to Papanui High School. Notes his response to being too tough on his students. Finds out if the influx of 1500 boys has had any effect on Papanui's female students. Talks to a student and a teacher about the day to day reality of campus sharing. Relays the principal's dreams for rebuilding the school. Briefly discusses the issues around and the schools involved in sharing campuses in Christchurch.

column8: Hurricanes, quakes and business interruption insurance
column9: Highlights the UK High Court's decision in the case of 'Orient Express Hotels vs Generali Global Risk' over an insurance dispute arising from the hurricane damage to New Orleans in 2005 to explain the business interruption (BI) clause in an insurance policy.

Covers the debate over the credibility of the 2011 Budget. Sums up the following areas of concern: doubt over revenue forecasts; cost of the Christchurch earthquake; lack of strategy; limited wage growth; unreliable overseas markets; national debt; household debt reduction; and a high NZ dollar. Looks at changes to Working for Families. Sums up the pros and cons of changes to the KiwiSaver scheme, citing comments by analysts Bernard Hickey, Mary Holm and Shamubeel Eaqub.

column8: 2011 Budget - enough to avert economic crisis?
column9: Covers the debate over the credibility of the 2011 Budget. Sums up the following areas of concern: doubt over revenue forecasts; cost of the Christchurch earthquake; lack of strategy; limited wage growth; unreliable overseas markets; national debt; household debt reduction; and a high NZ dollar. Looks at changes to Working for Families. Sums up the pros and cons of changes to the KiwiSaver scheme, citing comments by analysts Bernard Hickey, Mary Holm and Shamubeel Eaqub.

Records the volume of suggestions for rebuilding Christchurch, including from such overseas organisations as the global conference movement TED. Contrasts this with the difficulties, particularly access rights, faced by CBD building owners. Talks to owners Dean Marshall and Lisle Hood about concerns over emotional and financial reserves, higher than anticipated insurance costs, more exacting building codes, and finding tenants. Cites a property developer's suggestions about using the opportunity to revive the CBD by avoiding malls and office 'parks', and issuing bonds to retail investors. Describes the comments of urban designer James Lunday on rebuilding an urban space that people want to live in.

column8: Rebuilding Christchuch - the going gets tough
column9: Records the volume of suggestions for rebuilding Christchurch, including from such overseas organisations as the global conference movement TED. Contrasts this with the difficulties, particularly access rights, faced by CBD building owners. Talks to owners Dean Marshall and Lisle Hood about concerns over emotional and financial reserves, higher than anticipated insurance costs, more exacting building codes, and finding tenants. Cites a property developer's suggestions about using the opportunity to revive the CBD by avoiding malls and office 'parks', and issuing bonds to retail investors. Describes the comments of urban designer James Lunday on rebuilding an urban space that people want to live in.

column8: Kaikoura funeral for global symbol of earthquake
column9: Kaikoura funeral for global symbol of earthquake

Wonders if the Christchurch earthquakes have driven away retailers from High Street, and what might entice them to return. Talks to business owners, shoppers, urban designers, and landlords about the heritage buildings, the fashion boutiques, the low rents and the mix of creative people that made the area special. Notes some owners have relocated out of Christchurch. Cites comments by  C1 Expresso cafe owner Steve Crofsky about the organic growth of the area.

Gauges the effect of the Christchurch earthquakes on the city's cinemas. Seeks explanation for the differences in theatre-going between Wellington and Christchurch, noting the latter's lack of a suitable venue for film festivals or arthouse cinema. Talks to movie enthusiasts about the possibility of restoring the Odeon or the Isaac Theatre Royal.  Contains a short description of the Roxy Cinema in Miramar, restored to art deco opulence from its origins as the Capitol Theatre.

column8: Living and giving for those who died
column9: Reports on a trip to Kobe, Japan,  to evaluate how its citizens coped with the 1995 Hanshin earthquake. Talks to Misako Matsuura and Kiyoshi Matusuura, whose son died in the quake, about the volunteer group Hands they formed for survivors and visitors to the city. Emphasises the importance of resettling people in community groups and of monitoring mental health. Discusses post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) with Japanese psychologist Tomoko Osawa who visited NZ after the 22 Feb Christchurch earthquake.

Reflects on the sights seen on a three-hour remembrance walk around the cordon surrounding Christchurch's earthquake damaged CBD. Starts at the Colombo and St Asaph street intersection, noting the condition of various buildings, the signs people have put up, and the feelings this 'disaster tourism' evokes.

column8: Police, in numbers, reassure citizens on shattered streets of Christchurch
column9: Investigates crime patterns emerging following the relatively law abiding days following the 22 Feb Christchurch earthquake. Accompanies two out-of-town police officers on a 'trust and reasssurance' patrol around the city. Talks to Superintendent Andy McGregor about policing immediately after the earthquake, the effects of alcohol, and the anticipated effects of stress and hardship in the long term.

column8: Wedding bells ring for quake amputee
column9: Wedding bells ring for quake amputee

column8: Pilot was to help in quake work
column9: Pilot was to help in quake work

column8: Show goes on, despite quake; The show goes on
column9: Spotlights the planning of the play 'Five women wearing the same dress', a collaborative production between the Fortune Theatre and the Court Theatre. Talks to Fortune Theatre artistic director Lara Macgregor about the decision to move the production from Christchurch to Dunedin after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Informs of its season at the Fortune Theatre, Dunedin, 3-25 Jun 2011, followed by a run at the Aurora Theatre, Christchurch.

column8: Teen shot by cops had recently fled quake city
column9: Teen shot by cops had recently fled quake city

Discusses the post-earthquake mental issues that are affecting many Christchurch residents. Details the post-disaster relaxation techniques taught by US psychologist Dr James Gordon, and his desire to work in Christchurch. Relays a Christchurch woman's experience of being unable to cope. Documents the ongoing need for counselling in the city, citing the most common mental health problems people are facing. Talks to David Beaumont whose son died in the CTV building about his healing process.

column8: Robust decisions on rebuilding vital for all landowners; How best to deliver the bad news?
column9: Explains the process behind some of the big decisions to be made on the future of some Christchurch land. Notes where the damage delivered by the September 4 (2010) earthquake was able to be fixed by relatively modest civil works, the February 22 (2011) quake has caused much of the work that was under way to be reconsidered and presents a host of far greater engineering challenges. Includes maps that show the difference in scale between the two events. Includes comment from Vernon Small The Press national affairs editor.

column8: UC : university challenge; In the school of hard knocks
column9: Investigates the seriousness of the disruption to Canterbury University caused by the Canterbury and Christchurch earthquakes. Reveals the details of the damage to various building on the campus and the likely solutions once all the assessments have been completed. Debates the likelihood the site of the university campus will change. Assesses the number of students the university has lost and how many are likely to return either in term 2 or next year. Describes how students have managed to cope with the disruption, missing out on classes, having classes in different venues and helping out the citizens of Christchurch to remove the debris caused by the liquefaction.
Investigates the long-term impacts on Christchurch's multimillion dollar international student market caused by the earthquakes in Christchurch and Canterbury.

Reports that Roger Sutton takes on the helm of Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (Cera) and the positive response he has received by the residents of Christchurch. Details his schooling and his interest in mountain trekking, which his wife has experienced. Assesses the suitability of Roger Sutton to carry out the onerous task of organising the rebuilding of Christchurch and describes what he brings to the position as a person.

column8: Please Mother Nature, are we halfway there yet?
column9: Asks, after three big earthquakes in the city, what the odds are of a fourth one. Speaks to a number of scientists, including Kelvin Berryman of GNS Science and Professor Jarg Pettinga, head of geological science at Canterbury University, about assessing the hazard of more large earthquakes. Talks about the 6.3 magnitude earthquake that occurred on Monday 13 June 2011.
Describes how the relentlessness of the Christchurch earthquakes and the frustration of waiting for insurance companies to make decisions are taking its toll on the residents there.

Asks, after three big earthquakes in the city, what the odds are of a fourth one. Speaks to a number of scientists, including Kelvin Berryman of GNS Science and Professor Jarg Pettinga, head of geological science at Canterbury University, about assessing the hazard of more large earthquakes. Talks about the 6.3 magnitude earthquake that occurred on Monday 13 June 2011.

Looks at the 15-year battle to have the high-frequency radio mast at Ouruhia, near Bottle Lake, removed because of concerns about its electromagnetic field. Speaks to former Ouruhia resident Penny Hargreaves about the issue and her fight to get the case heard in the High Court. Highlights the recent warning issued by the World Health Organisation that radiofrequency electromagnetic fields could cause cancer. Talks about NZ's approach to the issue, including the NZ standard. Reports on the case of former Ouruhia resident Jan Zervos who believes she developed a tumour on her uterus because of the electromagnetic radiation emitted from the mast. Notes that the 151-metre Radio Network tower was recently removed, after being seriously damaged in the recent series of earthquakes in Canterbury, and replaced with a 25-metre tower for Civil Defence.

Cites a poll showing the number of Christchurch residents wanting to leave the city, following the 6.3 magnitude earthquake that occurred on Monday 13 June 2011. Talks to residents of Liggins Street, Burwood, about the liquefaction, waiting for official word on their homes, neighbours who have left, and the psychological toll. Anticipates a Government announcement on which areas of Christchurch will need to be abandoned.

Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1888. Reports in the 8 May edition about a public meeting to protest against 'an influx of Chinese into the colony', Princess Theatre, Dunedin, 7 May 1888. Describes the effects in Invercargill and Christchurch of a violent earthquake on 1 Sep felt in the South Island, 3 Sep 1888. Publishes the text of a letter to the editor about a sweatshop in Dunedin, and the reply from the editor after investigating the situation, 20 Oct 1888. Includes a photograph of the Sew Hoy dredge owned by the Shotover Big Beach Gold Mining Co.

column8: 'Rob put himself at risk of being killed - he saved at least three people'
column9: Recounts the bravery of the Canterbury dairy farmer who crawled into the Payne Gould Corporation (PGC) building in Christchurch to rescue people after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Cites his comments about the courage of those waiting to be saved, and the comments of some of the people he saved. Mentions the reaction of his wife Debbie Mackle to his being in the collapsed building. Notes his feelings on the demolition of the city's damaged buildings.

Explains the concept of a community time bank and community currency. Talks to Project Lyttelton chairwoman Margaret Jefferies about the town's six year old time bank initiative and how it helped in the aftermath of the recent earthquakes. Describes its origin as NZ's first time bank and how it has been used as a template for others in Kaitaia, Whakatane, Otaki, Gore and two suburbs in Christchurch. Compares the community building banks to local exchange trading systems (Lets), or green dollar schemes. Examines the currencies and organisation of Lets schemes in the Wairarapa, Golden Bay, and Whanganui. Also looks at the Out of our own backyards (Ooooby) organisation for trading homegrown produce, and the Local origin Ashhurst voluntary exchange (Loaves).

Features houses in Queenstown and Auckland designed by the South African born architect, looking at their uniform cladding and noting that they concern some neighbours. Cites his views about rebuilding earthquake damaged Christchurch.
Interviews EQC chief executive officer Ian Simpson. Responds to criticisms that the Commission is not responding quickly enough to Christchurch earthquake claims.
Interviews EQC chief executive officer Ian Simpson. Responds to criticisms that the Commission is not responding quickly enough to Christchurch earthquake claims.

column8: Cold sweat; Life-saver put aside his fears
column9: Recounts the bravery of the Canterbury dairy farmer who crawled into the Payne Gould Corporation (PGC) building in Christchurch to rescue people after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Cites his comments about the courage of those waiting to be saved, and the comments of some of the people he saved. Mentions the reaction of his wife Debbie Mackle to his being in the collapsed building. Notes his feelings on the demolition of the city's damaged buildings.

column8: Parents' burden lifted as quake victim identified
column9: Parents' burden lifted as quake victim identified

column8: Relish the power of a new generation
column9: Muses on different styles of political activism of baby boomers and Generation Y youth. Exemplifies the latter, describing the formation of the Student Volunteer Army (Sam Johnson), the Rebuild Christchurch website (Deon Swiggs),  the TEDxChChEQ conference (YChCh, Raf Manji), and the White Elephant Trust (Ant Rohan).  Cites examples where city council consultation with youth has not been fruitful. Reports on the US generated 2006 Cone Millenial Cause Study that sets out the characteristics of baby boomers, Generation X and Generation Y, noting the optimism and social entrepreneurship of the latter. Talks to Canterbury University Vice Chancellor Rod Carr about the need to adapt to and nourish the collaborative and active style of Gen Y.

Talks to a Christchurch woman whose mother died in the 22 Feb 2011earthquake. Describes her experience of hearing details about her mother's death at the inquest for those who died in the collapsed CTV building just when the 13 Jun 2011earthquake struck. Remembers her mother and recalls the encouraging words of Prince William on showing him a photograph of her. Contains biographical material.

Explains how emergency aid operations began after the Christchurch earthquakes. Lists the NGO 's Disaster Relief Forum (NDRF) members  in Christchurch and how they worked together with international and official organisations and community led groups. Gives examples of multiple organisations collaborating successfully with community groups, such as Rotary and the Salvation Army. Cites comments by international disaster rebuild expert Peter Kenyon on Christchurch's post-quake response.

column8: City's people rocked to core and living on the edge
column9: Having left Christchurch after the first earthquake in September the author returns after the February 22nd quake and finds most of her old haunts have been irreparably damaged or flattened completely. Visits the eastern suburbs where residents relate their feelings and plans for the future.

Explains the concept of a community time bank and community currency. Talks to Project Lyttelton chairwoman Margaret Jefferies about the town's six year old time bank initiative and how it helped in the aftermath of the recent earthquakes. Describes its origin as NZ's first time bank and how it has been used as a template for others in Kaitaia, Whakatane, Otaki, Gore and two suburbs in Christchurch. Compares the community building banks to local exchange trading systems (Lets), or green dollar schemes. Examines the currencies and organisation of Lets schemes in the Wairarapa, Golden Bay, and Whanganui. Also looks at the Out of our own backyards (Ooooby) organisation for trading homegrown produce, and the Local origin Ashhurst voluntary exchange (Loaves).

Features houses in Queenstown and Auckland designed by the South African born architect, looking at their uniform cladding and noting that they concern some neighbours. Cites his views about rebuilding earthquake damaged Christchurch.

Describes how life has been for Christchurch families who moved to Auckland following the 2010-2011 earthquakes, talking to Brian Haybittle who resettled his family to the North Shore. Estimates the net loss of population from Christchurch, providing a breakdown of numbers for different groups: school children, international and language students, university students, rest home residents, Housing NZ tenants, beneficiaries and superannuitants. Also gives figures and destinations for Christchurch residents who left NZ. Forecasts the numbers expected to move to Christchurch to participate in rebuilding the city.

Looks at the circumstances of three households, Brian Frisken's from Bexley, Tim Stephenson's from Kairaki Beach and Steve and Marie Davies' from Kaiapoi, after the Government announced its package for Canterbury homeowners with earthquake damaged land.
