Describes how the relentlessness of the Christchurch earthquakes and the frustration of waiting for insurance companies to make decisions are taking its toll on the residents there.

column8: Caution in most residential markets; More earthquake fallout
column9: Advises of the prevailing mood reflected in sales volumes and prices in the residential real estate market, drawing on a joint BNZ and Real Estate Institute survey of licensed real estate agents nationwide.  Gauges the effect on insurance of the latest 13 Jun earthquake in Christchurch. Looks at the issue of what makes a building 'untenable', focusing on attempts by FM Custodians to cancel leases held by GP 96.

Looks at the argument to turn the city's earthquake devastated eastern residential areas around the Avon River into a park. Speaks to freelance writer Ashley Campbell about her idea for an 'Avon River Park' and to landscape architect Di Lucas about her approach to the idea. Talks about the social media debate it has inspired and the negative response from Earthquake Recovery minister Gerry Brownlee to the plans.

column8: A rattle along for Ngai Tahu's legacy
column9: Focuses on the growing involvement of NgaÃÑi Tahu in the affairs of Canterbury. Reports that, with the scale of rebuilding being demanded in response to the Canterbury earthquakes, NgaÃÑi Tahu is set to become an even greater influence. Suggests that it is making some people nervous. Speaks to NgaÃÑi Tahu's kaiwhakahaere (tribe chairman) Mark Solomon about why forging a bicultural identity is important for the future of the region and the country as a whole, pointing out that demographic figures suggest NZ's future is 'increasingly brown'. Talks about the internal battles within its tribal ruling body Te RuÃÑnanga o NgaÃÑi Tahu (Tront) and its commercial operation NgaÃÑi Tahu Holdings. Looks at how NgaÃÑi Tahu is using its 1998 $170 million Treaty of Waitangi settlement to give its people a hand up, not a hand out, and how it has been driving the national agenda through pressure groups like the Iwi Leaders Forum, which represents the views of 57 iwi to Government. Speaks to Sacha McMeeking, the tribe's general manager of strategy and influence, about the letdown MaÃÑori are feeling over the way the Treaty of Waitangi has gone.

Honours the winners of the annual Sir Peter Blake Leadership Awards. Profiles the winner of the special award, student Sam Johnson, who organised the Student Volunteer Army clean up team following earthquakes in Christchurch; supreme award winner, public servant Dame Margaret Bazley; and 6 emerging leaders selected as showing great potential. Lists all supreme award winners since 2005.

column8: Quake's shock brings web team back to basics
column9: Quake's shock brings web team back to basics

Talks to the fashion designer who has relocated her boutique to her hometown after her business was destroyed in the Christchurch earthquake, 22 Feb 2011. Remarks on the tragedy of that day, which also claimed the life of her friend, Jillian Murphy, who was with her in the shop. Discusses her upbringing and career to date, and some of the labels she carries.

column8: Against all odds, team carry the torch for their city; The final crusade
column9: Looks at how the team reconfigured their 2011 Super 15 rugby season after the 22 February earthquake devastated Christchurch and their home ground, AMI Stadium. Speaks to a number of the team's players and staff members about their experiences. Notes that their 2011 record stands at 14-4 before playing in the Super 15 final against the Queensland Reds. Lists the distance travelled by the team, who did not play one game at their home ground during the 2011 season.

column8: Do you recognise this building? Clue : you are in Cashel Mall; Huge task ahead in central city; Tall buildings begin to disappear from city
column9: Reports on the progress of the inner city demolition of earthquake-shattered buildings in central Christchurch. Lists the various buildings due for demolition.

column8: Tale of two cities - the broken, and the shaken
column9: Compares the effects of the earthquakes in the east of Christchurch, where there is major damage, and the west, where it is shaken but still functioning. Talks to a resident from Aranui and one from Bishopdale about the different levels of house and property damage they are experiencing.

Looks at how some property owners were dealt a better hand than others in terms of how the Christchurch earthquakes affected their properties. Describes some of the different outcomes people are faced with including the consequences of having or not having replacement insurance, having undamaged buildings available to tenants, and the suggestion of moving the central business district.

Gives a precis of recent NZ financial history, noting the collapse of many finance companies and the earthquakes in Christchurch. Looks at indications of debt in Christchuch becoming harder to collect, credit agencies taking a softer approach, and trends showing that credit card debt is becoming more of a burden for the middle class and that consumers are cutting back on it. Discusses the state of NZ finances and legal powers for debt collection
Talks to landscape architect Di Lucas, about ROC (Renew Our City), and her firm notion of how post-earthquake Christchurch should be.

column8: Violent blow to oasis of calm
column9: Talks to Barry Gadsby, the owner of one of architect Peter Beaven's designed apartments in Cornwall St, St Albans, about his courtyard garden, a destination for hundreds of tourists over the years. Outlines the damage done to it by the Christchurch earthquakes.

column8: Young coffee devotee enjoys sweet success
column9: Talks to the young bachelor of commerce student at Aoraki Polytechnic about her use of social networking, particularly Twitter, to establish the Italian-made Bezzera coffee machine brand in NZ. Mentions that she was living in Christchurch until the earthquakes, and provided eyewitness accounts for overseas news networks because of her social networking profile.

Profiles the Dunedin-educated chairwoman of the NZ Historic Places Trust board. Talks to her about her education and career as a lawyer and judge. Describes the challenges facing the Trust in dealing with the effects of the Christchurch earthquakes on heritage buildings in the area, and comments on the need for more 'heritage artisans' to take charge of the architectural restoration of historic buildings. Cites other remarks she made to members of the University Club before the 13 Jun 2011 aftershocks in Christchurch.

Reveals that some 24 Wellington schools are potentially earthquake prone, listing the schools named by the City Council. Seeks comments from principals about the Council's findings. Discusses how the level of risk is assessed. Looks at the costs of strengthening the school buildings. Notes briefly the effects of pupil relocation resulting from the 22 Feb 2011 Christchurch earthquake.

Looks at pressures on the insurance industry of continuing earthquakes in the Christchurch area. Talks to Insurance Council chief executive Chris Ryan about the tensions between the reinsurers who insure the insurance companies and those involved in rebuilding the city. Describes the implications for commercial insurance in the future. Looks at legal issues arising around commercial leases and residential insurance.

Speaks to local GPs in Christchurch about the increases in anxiety / stress related illnesses due to the earthquakes. Discusses research about how the immune system and nervous system can be affected by stress. Talks to professor Andrew Hill, head of Auckland's South Auckland Clinical School about his findings from a study about relaxation after surgery and its affect on recovery rates. Gives advice on beating stress.

Looks at the effect of the recent Christchurch earthquakes on home insurance premiums and reinsurance. Supplies figures on the insurance cost of recent natural disasters. Looks at increases in contracting with international reinsurers and why some reinsurers are withdrawing from the market. Asks if NZ households may eventually be without comprehensive protection or be refused insurance on the basis of house inspections. Gives tips on what to look for when buying insurance and outlines the key issues arising from claims in Christchurch. Touches on how insurance company AMI has fared in the wake of the recent earthquakes.

column8: Your pass to the red zone
column9: Presents an aerial view of the central business district (CBD) red zone of the earthquake damaged city. Includes some ground level images. Notes that the photographs were taken on 8 Jul 2011.

Reports that the controversial mining practice of fracking, which may trigger earthquakes and contaminate drinking water, could get the go-ahead in Canterbury. Speaks to Dr Paul White, senior groundwater scientist for GNS Science, Green Party environment spokesperson David Clendon, and West Coast-based geologist Dr Murry Cave, of Western Exploration, about the possible impact of the process on the region, and to L&M Energy managing director Kent Anson about the company's applications. Explains how fracking works. Briefly outlines some overseas fracking issues, including an Australian senate inquiry into its use in the coalmines of New South Wales and Queensland.

Argues that the post-earthquake rebuilding period is the time to create a high-quality cycling infrastructure in Christchurch. Points to the successful Copenhagen method of encouraging people to commute by bicycle, which is usually known as 'Copenhagenisation'. Calculates how many litres of petrol would be saved in the city if people cycled at the same rate as those of Copenhagen. Considers the effects of cycling on public health. Touches on the results of an economic study in Portland, Oregon, after it underwent a Copenhagenisation in 2008. Looks at what needs to be done in the city to create a cycle network that appeals to commuters.

Looks at the process of recovery from the Canterbury earthquakes for the region's manufacturing sector. Speaks to a number of local manufacturers and industry leaders, including John Walley, chief executive of the NZ Manufactures and Exporters Association, about some of the issues facing the sector, such as staff retention and the high value of the NZ dollar, and the rebuild process.

Looks at examples of co-housing or common-ownership properties in Christchurch, Colorado and California. Describes the Clifton Hill development, the work of architect Roger Buck. Extols the benefits of shared facilities and communal resources. Suggests this type of housing may suit earthquake damaged Christchurch.

column8: Quakes' many stories to go on the record
column9: Reports on how the experience of the Christchurch earthquakes will become the most comprehensively studied and archived disaster in NZ's history. Speaks to National Library of NZ associate chief librarian Ronald Milne about how the library has been steadily working to amass an earthquake archive, which includes an oral history project, commissioned photographs, harvesting of earthquake-related websites, and earthquake-related ephemera. Backgrounds the launch of the Ministry of Culture and Heritage's new web project called 'Quake Stories'. Talks to Paul Millar, an associate professor in the College of Arts at Canterbury University, about the plans for the 'Ceismic consortium', which will see Canterbury build up a unique archive of quake experiences.

Talks to the Wanganui-raised artist about 'Preoccupied', his survey exhibition of works from 1998, Monumental Gallery, Dunedin, until 4 Sep 2011. Informs that the exhibition (originally entitled 'Reverb') had been installed at the Centre of Contemporary Art (CoCA), Christchurch, but was disrupted by the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Discusses his involvement in saving heritage buildings and how he incorporates this interest into his paintings. Touches on the current situation for the arts communities in Christchurch after the earthquakes.

column8: Archivists dig quake stories out of rubble

column9: Quakes generate plans for off-grid homes
Talks to film makers Angus Benfield and Patrick Gillies about the comedy they made in Christchurch in 2009 that includes footage of city areas since destroyed by the earthquakes.

Reflects on the disasters that have hit the country in the last 12 months, including the Pike River Mine explosion, the Christchurch earthquake, and the Auckland tornado. Talks to West Coast Mayor Tony Kokshoorn, historian Professor Philippa Mein Smith from the University of Canterbury and Christchurch Mayor Bob Parker about the traumatic year.

column8: Hard times bring out our best side
column9: Reports on how random acts of kindness can make the world a better place. Speaks to Megan Singleton who, along with three friends, started the annual Random Acts of Kindness (RAK) Day. Highlights some RAK events. Touches on some RAK after the 22 Feb Christchurch Earthquake.

Interviews two speakers at the International Speakers Series in Christchurch about their ideas for rebuilding the city after the earthquakes. Talks to Timaru born, London based architect Sam Martin about his concept of a park along the Avon River and his ideas for a central earthquake information centre. Talks to Victorian Bushfire Reconstruction and Recovery Authority  planner Kerry O'Neill about lessons learned in Victoria and her views on draft plans for Christchurch. Profiles briefly participants in the International Speakers Series being held at the University of Canterbury, 27-30 Aug.

column8: The Draft Plan : five key matters
column9: Presents opinion by the town planner on the post-earthquake Draft Plan document created by the Christchurch City Council. Sets out the five issues that the author considers need immediate resolution, focusing on council resources, public transportation, and development strategies. Provides a summary of the author's credentials.

Throws the spotlight on myths about opera, noting the current health of the NBR New Zealand Opera. Previews the company's performance of 'Cavalleria Rusticana' and 'Pagliacci' at the St James Theatre, Wellington, 27 and 30 Aug, and 1 and 3 Sep. Discusses sponsorship, typical costs of production, surtitles, lean sopranos, ticket prices and audiences. Looks at the risks of staging lesser known operas, and the effect of low fees on NZ singers. Touches on the condition of Christchurch opera venues. Mentions the 6 Oct appearance of Placido Domingo at an earthquake recovery concert in Christchurch.

Talks to a number of scientists, including Dr Mark Quigley, senior lecturer in active tectonics and geomorphology at the University of Canterbury, about some of the lessons they have learned from the region's recent earthquakes and aftershocks.

Focuses on the NZ Skeptics. Speaks to NZ Skeptics media spokeswoman Vicki Hyde about the aims of the non-profit incorporated society, which she likens to a Consumer's Institute for the mind. Talks about the lack of science-based knowledge within the media. Touches on some of the poor or shoddy science the Skeptics have issues with. Mentions the society's 2011 'Bent Spoon Award' for journalistic gullibility, which was awarded to media outlets and personalities who took Ken Ring's earthquake prediction claims at face value. Notes that the NZ Skeptics 2011 annual conference is being held in Christchurch on 27-28 Aug.

column8: Mayor an optimist in face of misfortune; One year on September 4, 2010
column9: Interviews the Christchurch mayor one year after the Darfield earthquake. Talks about the effect on the mayoral election, and how he has fared politically, psychologically and personally.

column8: Shock to the system; extent of disaster never imagined
column9: Explores criticism that the EQC was unprepared for the size of Christchurch earthquakes, for multiple earthquakes, and for the number of claims.  Talks to chief executive officer Ian Simpson about EQC's response to an external review (2008) that highlighted inadequacies.  Looks at the post-earthquake functions taken on by the Commission that are outside its mandate.  Asks if the EQC model is sound.  Briefly describes the function of the EQC. Shows statistics for claims and amounts paid for the 2010 and 2011 earthquakes.

Talks to scientist Dr Neil Whitehead about his research into possible indicators of the 4 Sep 2010 Canterbury earthquake.  Notes that  the study of electronic precursors to earthquakes began in Japan after the 1995 Kobe earthquake. Discusses the detection of electromagnetic radiation signals in the ground, in water, in the sky, by animals, by humans, by electronic gadgetry, and in the form of earthquake lights. Mentions a successful earthquake prediction in Chian in 1975. Comments on the response from Cantabrians to his response for information.

column8: Scientist took the shakes out of the quakes
column9: Scientist took the shakes out of the quakes

Observes the impact of the 2010 and 2011 Canterbury/Christchurch earthquakes on the insurance industry.  Talks to Insurance Council of New Zealand (ICNZ) chief executive Chris Ryan, Insurance Brokers Association (IBANZ) chief executive Gary Young, and AMI Insurance chief executive John Balmforth about the costs to insurers and reinsurers.  Highlights the current precarious state of AMI.  Speculates on how high insurance premiums will go up as a result.

Assesses the state of the Canterbury business community one year after the Darfield earthquake. Looks at the effect on CBD businesses of the 22 February 2011 earthquake. Provides some statistics on the state of various industries. Highlights the survival of Sydenham IT company Truescape, sheet metal fabrication shop Prometal, and residential building company Stonewood Homes.

Reports on the response and services provided by the Christchurch Hospital Emergency Department (ED) following earthquake in Christchurch. Points out six lessons learned, supplied by ED acting head Mike Ardagh.

Overviews coverage of the Canterbury earthquakes. Observes the public thirst for scientific knowledge sparked by the 4 September 2010 Darfield earthquake. Remarks on some of the egoic responses of scientists to suddenly being in the spotlight.

Talks to Louise Deans about the destruction of the Homebush homestead in the Darfield earthquake. Recalls the events of the day, 4 September 2010. Reveals plans to build a new house close to the original site. Recalls Deans family history dating back to William Deans and John Deans taking up a lease in Canterbury in 1843, and the building of the homestead in 1851.  Documents damage to other buildings in Hororata - St John's church and the Hororata Hotel - and notes the creation of the Hororata Community Trust aimed at reviving the community.

Describes the social and cultural response of Canterbury to the 2010/2011 earthquakes that hit the region. Looks at changes in vocabulary ('munted'), dress and grooming codes, civic identity, house decoration, earthquake music and merchandise, and emergency preparations.

Highlights the research into earthquake resistant buildings by Structural Timber Innovation Company. Talks to Canterbury University engineer Dr Stefano Pampanin about the structure of the company's headquarters, a wooden building that withstood the 22 February 2011 earthquake. Notes his work with NZ born seismic designer Nigel Priestley, the use made of Greek temple structure, and the reason for focusing on using  wood. Mentions other buildings that use the company's earthquake-resistant technology.

Visits Toyama, Japan, to talk to students and staff of the Toyama College of Foreign Languages about their experience of the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake which destroyed Christchurch's  CTV building in which they were attending English classes at King's Education language school. Talks to College deputy director Kuniaki Kawahata about reconciling the death of his daughter Kyoko Kawahata in the earthquake. Speaks with four Japanese survivors of the quake and a NZer language teacher. Records the experience of the parents while in Christchurch to recover their children's bodies. Remarks on the resilience of the students who have resumed their studies in Japan. Relays the experience of NZ firefighter Paul Rodwell who rescued Japanese students from the CTV building.

Reports on 'The city as memory', and 'Imagined futures' panel discussions held in Christchurch under the auspices of the Scape public art biennial and Christchurch Arts Festival. Notes the poignancy of the discussion topics given the earthquake damage sustained on 22 Feb 2011. Summarises the views of the panellists art historian Jonathan Mane-Wheoki (on pre-earthquake Christchurch); landscape architect Di Lucas (on pre-human Canterbury); artist Anton Parsons, architect William Fulton (on the city's architectural influences); and Lyttelton sound artist and academic Bruce Russell (on social history and preserving ruins). Also presents the observations of landscape architect William Field (on public artworks created for Scape); Melbourne artist Ash Keating (on his installation Gardensity); Christchurch City Council urban design advisor Hugh Nicholson (on urban design); Auckland architectural critic and lecturer Bill McKay (about the pace of rebuilding); and Australian writer Simon Sellars (about urban renewal).

Talks to immigrants who have settled in Christchurch about whether the recent earthquakes have shaken their resolve to stay in New Zealand. Talks to Britons Rachel Wiscombe and Joe Wiscombe; French brothers and chefs Frederic Berhault, Vincent Berhault and Benjamin Berhault; Americans Kris Woods and Jim Woods; Netherlander Anneke Vollebregt and Brazilian Mikael Ekman; and Britons Maria Romero and Nick Blackburn.

column8: Dance student's fortunate decision before the earthquake hit; A name to remember; Massive upheaval; Home
column9: Presents essays, a poem and an original work of art from six pupils at Bayfield High School. Relates the stories of two people, including a former pupil, who survived the 6.3 magnitude earthquake in Christchurch, 22 Feb 2011, as told by Emily-Kate Robinson and Victoria Saunders. Describes the qualities of her friend, a popular Swedish student named Agnes, who has since returned to Sweden. Includes the poem 'Home' by Britta Hamill, and a pop art work and commentary by Joshua Hunter.

Talks to the police forensic photographer about his experience in the aftermath of the 22 Feb 2011 Christchurch earthquake, images of which have been published in the book 'Christchurch 22.2 : Beyond the cordon / through the eyes of New Zealand Police photographers', featuring photographs by about 20 forensic photographers in the weeks following the earthquake.

Covers the state of the insurance industry in NZ. Reports on a NZ delegation to Europe to meet with reinsurers, noting remarks by Earthquake Recovery Minister Gerry Brownlee about resulting increases in reinsurance costs. Warns of the effect of insurance companies currently withholding cover to Christchurch businesses and individuals. Touches on the Government's financial support of AMI Insurance.

Showcases some of the work of police photographers in the wake of the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake in Christchurch. Notifies of the publication of a book featuring images taken inside the red zone, 'Christchurch 22.2: Beyond the cordon: Through the eyes of New Zealand police photographers'. Cites comments about demeanour of the Japanese urban search and rescue team.

column8: Couple at 'end of tether' after insurance drama
column9: Talks to St Martins couple Barry Chapman and Carole Chapman about their dealings with Tower Insurance following disagreement over whether their house could be rebuilt following damage in the Christchurch earthquakes.

Traces the steps that Perpetual Trust has taken to recover from the deaths of 10 employees in the 22 Feb earthquake, talking to CEO Patrick Middleton. Announces the company has opened a new office in Addington, Christchurch, after its premises in the PGC building were destroyed. Relays the surviving employees' experiences of the earthquake and their post-quake recovery.

column8: The woe of hair today but gone tomorrow
column9: Investigates the phenomenon of hair loss among Canterbury residents following the earthquakes in Christchurch. Presents facts on the condition known as alopecia. Talks to Gendi Roberts, Ashleigh Calvert and Janine Antram about coping with hair loss. Talks to Ms Antram about her wig provider business and the possible causes of alopecia. Mentions a service payment available for people who need wigs and hairpieces.

column8: In the poo ; The estuary a toilet bowl again
column9: Investigates the condition of the Avon-Heathcote Estuary following the Christchurch earthquakes. Describes the research being carried out on the water and algae at the estuary. Remarks on the resilience of the locals and researchers to the smell and contamination. Gives a short history of wastewater treatment in Christchurch. Informs of the amount of untreated sewage and wastewater that has entered the area's rivers, estuary and sea. Gauges the effect of the Christchurch earthquakes on estuarine health, noting the role played by liquefaction. Presents an environmental forecast for the area.

Reviews three concerts that remembered the recent earthquakes, 'Christchurch sings' (4 Sep), 'Christchurch memorial' (25 Sep) and 'NZSO odes to joy' (27 Sep), which were part of the Christchurch Arts Festival (12 Aug to 2 Oct).

Informs of the corporate interest in the hydrocarbon potential of the Canterbury basin. Talks to spokesperson for the Texas oil company Anadarko Alan Seay about its drilling plans. Names the other oil and gas companies interested in obtaining permits for the area. Discusses the Government's goal to increase exploration and production investment, citing the comments of Energy Minister Gerry Brownlee on the size and exploration potential of NZ's large exclusive economic zone (EEZ). Looks at the content of the proposed EEZ and Contintental Shelf (Environmental Effects) Bill aimed at managing the effects of offshore exploration activities. Reports criticism of the new Environmental Protection Agency and its ability to mitigate any drilling related disasters. Explains the role of the Ministry for the Environment and Maritime New Zealand in policing NZ's EEZ. Relays the reaction to offshore exploration of Christchurch mayor Bob Parker and conveys his focus on promoting energy efficiency through the Christchurch Agency for Energy (CAfE).

Chats about the changes in NZ eating habits, the current demand for microgreens, and their weathering the Christchurch earthquakes.

column9: Bali quake sends Kiwi teacher flying

Presents an analysis and forecasts for the South Island economy. Talks about global concerns undermining business confidence, improved consumer confidence, increased house sales and consents, unemployment, and CPI (consumer price index) inflation.

column8: Mainland monitor : city council business divide
column9: Looks at the troubled relations between the Christchurch City Council and the business community over the city's rebuild after the 2010 and 2011 earthquakes. Talks to some critics of the council's draft city plan.
Talks to the band about their debut album.

column8: Small-town jurors feel earthquake pressure; Jury trials to be held at former barracks site
column9: Reviews the impact on jurors and the justice system after Christchurch courthouses were put out of action after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Talks to a businessman, local residents, the Ministry of Justice, lawyers and Corrections officials about the implications of having to shift all trials from Christchurch to other South Island cities and towns. Informs that jury trials will resume in a temporary complex on the old King Edward Barracks site in the Christchurch CBD from early 2012.

column8: At last, doors to open in the city
column9: Talks to the chairman of the Restart the Heart Trust about the Re:Start project aimed at rebuilding the retail sector in the ruined city centre. Discusses the new retail area that will open to the public on 29 Oct 2011, made of repurposed shipping containers. Mentions a new Augmented Reality (AR) phone application developed at the University of Canterbury that will be released on the same day, allowing people to 'see life-sized virtual models of buildings ... where the real buildings used to be'.  Talks about the psychological impact of the earthquakes and their aftermath on residents, and the challenge of creating an economically viable city in partnership with property owners and the Christchurch City Council. Overviews his interest and experience in city revitalisation beginning in the late 1970s.

column8: Fabric of memory falling to pieces; Fabric of memory falling to pieces in the demolished city centre
column9: Focuses on the psychological impact for residents of Christchurch who will soon be re-entering an empty central city that has been demolished and cleared of earthquake debris. Observes that our memories, emotions and experiences help to form our mental pictures of cities, and when buildings are demolished or rebuilt in a short time it has a 'devastating effect' on these mental images. Includes remarks from design historian Douglas Lloyd Jenkins, writer Martin Edmond and others about their response to major changes to city architecture in Auckland, Sydney and elsewhere, and cites comment from Islay McLeod, Bruce Russell and Adrienne Rewi about the Christchurch CBD.

Features 'Otahuna', a historic homestead in Canterbury designed by architect Frederick Strouts and built in 1895 by Sir Heaton Rhodes. Talks to one of the co-owners about the challenge of rebuilding the homestead, now a boutique luxury accommodation venue, after the earthquakes of 4 Sep 2010 and 22 Feb 2011. Traces the history of the homestead.

Talks to the former childhood neighbours from Ryan St, Linwood, Christchurch. Focuses on their work to transform the driveway of their workplace, Gary Clarke Plastics, into an attractive garden environment after the company suffered liquefaction damage.

column8: 'Remarkable New Zealander' who made things happen
column9: Pays tribute to the late operatic tenor and sports administrator. Praises his administrative ability in a variety of sectors, including organising a benefit concert for Christchurch earthquake relief headlined by friend Placido Domingo.

Features 'Otahuna', a historic homestead in Canterbury designed by architect Frederick Strouts and built in 1895 by Sir Heaton Rhodes. Talks to one of the co-owners about the challenge of rebuilding the homestead, now a boutique luxury accommodation venue, after the earthquakes of 4 Sep 2010 and 22 Feb 2011. Traces the history of the homestead.

column8: New Vero chief grasps the nettle
column9: Speaks to newly appointed chief executive of insurance company Vero in NZ, Gary Dransfield, about how the 2010 and 2011 Canterbury earthquakes changed the property investment scene around the country.

Looks at the demolition of buildings in Christchurch, especially heritage buildings, and reports on criticism that this is unnecessary. Sketches the scale of demolitions and reports on international engineers Kit Miyamoto and Michael King's claims that many of the buildings could have been fixed for 20%-30% of the cost of new buildings. Discusses reasons why Christchurch owners might seek exaggerated damage estimates and settlements for demolitions through the Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (CERA). Reports on the urban renewal of Newcastle in NSW following an earthquake and other urban revitilisation efforts in Australia.

column8: Christchurch's heritage buildings are a "must keep"; Newcastle rising
column9: Looks at the demolition of buildings in Christchurch, especially heritage buildings, and reports on criticism that this is unnecessary. Sketches the scale of demolitions and reports on international engineers Kit Miyamoto and Michael King's claims that many of the buildings could have been fixed for 20%-30% of the cost of new buildings. Discusses reasons why Christchurch owners might seek exaggerated damage estimates and settlements for demolitions through the Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (CERA). Reports on the urban renewal of Newcastle in NSW following an earthquake and other urban revitilisation efforts in Australia.

Looks at the long-term toll the Canterbury earthquakes are taking on many people around Christchurch and Canterbury. Talks about the recognised sequence of psychological stages that follow a natural disaster like an earthquake. Speaks to Professor Bruce Glavovic of the Massey University Joint Centre for Disaster Research and Christchurch Mayor Bob Parker about the mental recovery process, and to a number of residents, including Don Elder, Solid Energy chief executive and spokesman for the Christchurch Business Leaders' Group, about their experiences.
Talks to the columnist about life in the early days of the post-earthquake city, as depicted in her columns and a new book 'Old Bucky & me : dispatches from the Christchurch earthquake'.

Talks about how a lack of human intervention due to the Christchurch earthquakes has not stopped her garden from flourishing. Notes the various roadside wild plants that she sees around Flaxmere and Hawarden.

Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in early 2011. Covers the aftermath of the Christchurch 22 Feb earthquake, giving updates for 19 Mar and 14 Jun (23 Feb); the earthquake and tsunami on Japan's northeast coast, including a 16 Mar update on the nuclear radiation leaking from a Fukushima atomic power plant (12 Mar); and the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton at Westminster Abbey, UK, (30 Apr). Includes brief articles on the death of Osama bin Laden, a windstorm in Dunedin and the opening of the Forsyth Barr Stadium in Dunedin.
Pays tribute to the late athlete, coach and sports administrator who was killed in the Christchurch earthquake, 22 Feb 2011. Talks to associates about the impact of his loss to athletics.

column8: Lucky to be alive, says woman hurt in quake
column9: Lucky to be alive, says woman hurt in quake

Investigates whether the Christchurch City Council is listening to local communities such as Sumner and Lyttelton in its handling of suburb earthquake recovery plans. Seeks comment from Jenny Ridgen, the city council planner responsible for the suburban centres programme, about the council's master plans for Sydenham and Lyttelton. Talks to local residents of Lyttelton and Sumner about  their frustrations with the slow pace of the recovery.

Reflects on his upbringing in the suburb of Brooklands during the 1960s. Comments on the Government decision to designate the community as being in the 'red zone', which will wipe the village from the map.

column8: Helping Chch rise up; Busy building a vision for Christchurch, project by project
column9: Talks to the man who is emerging as a rebuild entrepreneur for the region through the business owned by his family trust. Discusses the challenges and opportunities that have come after the Canterbury and Christchurch earthquakes.  Focuses on the Re:Start retail project in Cashel Mall, Christchurch, constructed from shipping containers, and other construction projects and priorities in the city. Seeks comment from Registered Master Builders chief executive Warwick Quinn.

column8: Award finalist inspired by quake-bereaved student
column9: Award finalist inspired by quake-bereaved student

column8: Sperm-donor father kept his wife in the dark
column9: Reports how American politician Bill Johnson, who has spent most of this year in Christchurch helping run the earthquake recovery, has been meeting women online who want help to get pregnant, without telling his wife or the individual women concerned about what he was doing. Looks at the concerns raised by his actions as a sperm donor in the fertility medicine community, whose guidelines recommend donations are made in the regulated environment of a fertility clinic, and that no man provide sperm donations to more than four families. Highlights the complexity of fertility law. Talks to his wife, Kathy Johnson, about her reaction to the news.

column8: Brave teen put body on line
column9: Talks to the recipient of a Community Hero award for his efforts in wedging himself between his severely injured aunt and a collapsed chimney after the Feb 22 Christchurch earthquake.

column8: Before Christchurch, there was Wellington's quake; Engaging story of food and life; Collection proof poet can get better with age
column9: Before Christchurch, there was Wellington's quake; Engaging story of food and life; Collection proof poet can get better with age

column8: PGC building's susceptibility known; disregarding it cost 18 lives in quake
column9: Examines the findings so far of the Canterbury earthquakes royal commission into the structure of the Pyne Gould Corporation building which collapsed partially in the Feb 2011 earthquake. Outlines strengthening measures carried out since 1966, reports from individual occupants on the building's status after the September 2010 earthquake, and points out differing interpretations of the term earthquake 'safe'. Presents a visual sequence of the building's collapse.

Acknowledges the part played by Christchurch teachers in the aftermath of the Feb 22 2011 earthquake. Looks at the uncertainty schools and teachers face in the face of dropping rolls and damaged school buildings. Speaks to New Zealand Principals Association Peter Simpson about other issues facing schools: primary school league tables, competition in a co-operative profession, charter schools, widening gaps in student ability, and lack of consultation with government officials.

column8: Lego man puts blocks in place
column9: Presents divergent opinions on the performance and design of the Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (CERA). Talks to Cera chief executive Roger Sutton about the perceptions, his views of the organisation's structure and powers,  the people he has chosen for his management team, and the pace at which the group is proceeding. Focuses on general manager of operations Warwick Isaacs, who is responsible for signing off the demolition of Christchurch buildings. Chronicles the history of the organisation since the Sep 2010 earthquake.

Reports on the resignation of the Dean of Christ Church Cathedral Peter Beck and the suggestion that he fell out with Bishop Victoria Matthews over the future of the cathedral, which was severely damaged in the Feb 2011 earthquake. Talks about the break down in relations between church leaders and the Christchurch City Council heritage staff over the building. Presents a brief history of the cathedral.

column8: Curtain to rise at new theatre
column9: Reports Christchurch's Court Theatre will begin a new life in a new location in Bernard Street, Addington after the old theatre in the Christchurch Arts Centre was destroyed in the February 22, 2011 earthquake.

Charts the progress of a community forum, a cross-section of Christchurch people, set up by Earthquake Recovery Minister Gerry Brownlee as his official sounding board, one of three checks and balances on his ministerial powers.

Talks to owner of Smith's Bookshop, Barry Hancox about his plans to restart his business as soon as is practicable. Smith's Bookshop had become a Christchurch institution but was destroyed in February's earthquake where it had been trading and the business had been going since 1894.
Writes how household cover in NZ has changed forever after the sequence of earthquakes in Christchurch in the past 15 months.

Discusses Christchurch in terms of its most influential people, suggesting that power struggles have been affected by the 2010 and 2011 earthquakes. Briefly profiles the following twelve people, describing their roles in the rebuilding of Christchurch following the earthquakes: Gerry Brownlee, Roger Sutton, Tony Marryatt, Bob Parker, Mark Solomon, Andrew Holden, Dame Margaret Bazley, Don Elder, Peter Townsend, David Meates, Bruce Irvine, and Rod Carr.

column8: Student rallied thousands for quake clean-up army
column9: Student rallied thousands for quake clean-up army
Spotlights the local heroes that have helped and made a difference to earthquake ravaged Christchurch during the past year.

Asks the following NZers what they were doing at age 20 and what advice they would give that younger self: food writer Annabel Langbein, Labour MP David Cunliffe (48), satirist John Clarke (63), broadcaster Mike Hosking, broadcaster Paul Holmes (61), Christchurch mayor Bob Parker (58), chef and food writer Alison Holst (73), musician Dave Dobbyn (54), photographer Marti Friedlander (83), playwright Roger Hall (72), MP and former broadcaster Maggie Barry (52), artist Dick Frizzell (68), scientist Sir Ray Avery (64), film-maker Vincent Ward (55), former All Black captain Sean Fitzpatrick (48), and novelist Lloyd Jones (56).

column8: Tackling the monster without : 'Landfall' on quakes
column9: Reviews the issue themed 'Christchurch and beyond', noting the ongoing editorship of David Eggleton.
Looks at how various Christchurch home gardens are faring after the earthquakes.

column8: Shearer's message just what Kiwis needed
column9: Takes up David Shearer's view that a beautiful NZ is not enough to keep young NZders home to build a career, nor is it enough to attract talented overseas people here. Comments on David Shearer's predisposition to support 'innovative government policies and work in a bi-partisan fashion'. Notes the continuing earthquakes in Christchurch will affect the government's ability to plan for economic development and the euro crisis is not having a positive affect either.

Details the demolition of buildings in Christchurch's central business district. Talks to engineering experts about the lessons learned from the collapse of CBD buildings during the Christchurch earthquakes. Focuses on soil composition, adequacy of engineering standards, and the danger of poorly designed reinforced concrete buildings. Registers criticism of the Canterbury Earthquakes Royal Commission membership and some of its findings so far on the collapse of the Pyne Gould Corporation (PGC) building.

column8: Jade succeeding with push into great unknown
column9: Spotlights the winner of the 'Otago Daily Times' Southern Business of the Year. Talks to its managing director Craig Richardson about the challenges of carrying out its three-year plan after the Christchurch earthquakes, and its successes, including the establishment of an office in San Francisco.

Discusses the exploration of oil and gas using fracking.  Defines the process, explaining why it is regarded as unconventional.  Sets out its contribution to the US energy industry. Explains the reasons for controversy over the practice in the US and Australia. Differentiates the chemicals used by exploration companies in NZ.  Provides an illustration of the engineering method used in NZ.  Talks to L&M Energy managing director Kent Anson about the company's applications to mine coal seam gas in Canterbury. Documents the resistance by Taranaki farmers Sarah Robert and David Morrison to fracking by Canadian based Tag Oil. Talks to American geophysicist Michael Hasting about links between fracking and earthquakes and asks if the procedure should be used in Canterbury.  Reports on groundwater contamination close to the Kapuni gas fields, where gas is extracted by Shell Todd Oil Services.  Relays concerns voiced by individuals and groups in NZ, and passes on the warning from the spokesman of Apache, a US based company operating on the North Island East Coast.

column8: To insure or not to insure?
column9: Delves into the philosophy of the insurance industry, focusing on its importance and some of its shortcomings in the wake of the Christchurch earthquakes. Seeks comment from Waitaki District Council strategy group manager Richard Mabon, who provided a report to the council about its insurance options. Talks to Oamaru Whitestone Civic Trust chairman Phil Hope and Vicar Tim Hurd of St Luke's Anglican Church, Oamaru, about the options they have investigated for the properties in their care.

column8: Earthquakes teach unexpected lessons; Loath to move back to centre
column9: Talks to the businessman and former clinical psychologist, co-owner of four gift stores in Christchurch with partner Anita Cessford, about the impact of the Christchurch earthquakes on the retail chain and the lessons they have learned. Discusses the earthquake on Boxing Day 2010 that led to the City Mall store in the CBD being 'red-stickered', which in hindsight was a 'fortunate' occurrence. Describes the effects of the earthquakes on staff and his own experiences with bureaucracy and insurance companies. Explains the decision not to reopen shops in the central city.

column8: Legacy at risk as city crumbles
column9: Reports on the tough decisions heritage experts face in central Christchurch after the 2010 and 2011 earthquakes. Speaks to Christchurch Arts Centre director Ken Franklin about the reality of the situation for the complex, architectural historian and heritage planner Jenny May about the loss of memory of the city, and University of Canterbury Associate Professor in Art History Ian Lochhead about the concerns surrounding the hasty demolition of heritage buildings.

column8: At the sharp end of recovery
column9: Focuses on the work of Recover Canterbury. Provides three case studies (Winnie Bagoes, Embrayce Skin and Beauty, and High Speed Doors) to illustrate how the organisation helps local business owners battling with post-earthquake issues. Explains how business owners can get help.

column8: Cera leads the way to recovery
column9: Talks to Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (CERA) economic recovery general manager Steve Wakefield. Names and backgrounds the business and government members of his team, and lists and discusses the team's economic priorities for 2012. Remarks on the level of international and local interest in investing in the Christchurch CBD, and on the decision of two Government departments to locate out of the CBD.

column8: Terrified mum feels trapped in quake zone
column9: Terrified mum feels trapped in quake zone

column8: Refuge as busy as ever in hard times; Women's refuge : inside a safe house
column9: Spotlights the work of Te Whare Pounamu Dunedin Women's Refuge. Talks to residential services manager Darlene Gore and residential services worker Kerri Oliver about the increased demand for their services in the wake of the recession, stress and the Christchurch earthquakes. Visits a safe house in Dunedin and talks to Kerri Oliver about the property. Provides facts about the refuge for those who want to help, or are seeking help.

Investigates the crisis that is ripping apart the Christchurch City Council (CCC). Speaks to protest organiser Peter Lynch, the Reverend Mike Coleman, leader of the Wider Earthquake Communities' Action Network (WeCan), former developer Hugh Pavletich, and Christchurch Mayor Bob Parker about the issues that have led to a public protest outside the council offices and the demand for emergency mid-term local government elections in the city. Talks about the controversy around CCC chief executive Tony Marryatt's $68,000 pay rise.

Speaks to three Christchurch families about the changes in the behaviour of their children after the 22 Feb earthquake and the ongoing aftershocks, and to child and family psychologist Melanie Patterson about the Journey of Hope programme that is designed to create more resilient children. Provides tips for how to deal with mild anxiety in children.

column8: From the quake, a gift of life to a sister
column9: From the quake, a gift of life to a sister

column8: Shake-up heading in EQC's direction; Quakes blow benchmark
column9: Speaks to Earthquake Recovery Minister Gerry Brownlee and EQC (Earthquake Commission) chief executive Ian Simpson about how an upcoming review of the scheme will affect the insurance cover of householders. Talks to Ian Simpson about why the Canterbury earthquakes have not changed the commission's view of its worse-case scenario for Wellington in relation to how much money it will need in reserves.

column8: Quake survivor shows the miracle of the body
column9: Speaks to the earthquake survivor about her recovery from multiple injuries caused by being crushed beneath the rubble of the City Mall.

column8: Rippling aftershocks; Evaluating the EQC one year on; Wellington quake would spark 150,000 claims
column9: Speaks to Earthquake Recovery Minister Gerry Brownlee and EQC (Earthquake Commission) chief executive Ian Simpson about how an upcoming review of the scheme will affect the insurance cover of householders. Talks to Ian Simpson about why the Canterbury earthquakes have not changed the commission's view of its worse-case scenario for Wellington in relation to how much money it will need in reserves.

column8: Airport build a boost for city
column9: Speaks to Christchurch International Airport chief executive Jim Boult, who is also chairman of the Christchurch and Canterbury Tourism partnership, about the role of the airport in the region. Reports on the progress of the Christchurch International Airport's domestic terminal rebuild.

Considers the city's recovery one year after the devastating 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Tells the recovery stories of a number of residents: red-zoners Jenny and Allan Faulkner, and Regan and John Helsloot, community builder Marnie Kent, business owner Ange Leonard, artistic director Ross Gumbley, heritage owner and entrepreneur Alan Slade, and kiosk owner Ian Carter.

Considers the city's recovery one year after the devastating 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Tells the recovery stories of a number of residents: red-zoners Jenny and Allan Faulkner, and Regan and John Helsloot, community builder Marnie Kent, business owner Ange Leonard, artistic director Ross Gumbley, heritage owner and entrepreneur Alan Slade, and kiosk owner Ian Carter.

column8: Inside CTV's collapse; 'A miracle has happened and I have not survived to abandon my dreams. More than ever it was a time to live now';
column9: Describes the time leading up to, during and a short time after the February 22, 2011 Christchurch earthquake by some of those who worked in the Canterbury Television building.

Recounts Christine Murray's experience of being inside the PGC building in Christchurch when the February 22 earthquake struck, how she was help out of the building and how her husband Stephen, eventually managed to locate her at Christchurch Hospital. Describes the museum they run and own (The Time Machine) which has items of popular culture memorabilia and nostalgia.

column8: He was God's little ray of sunshine; The brave companion of a man who was doomed to die
column9: Follows the experience of attempting to extricate Carey Bird from the much damaged Pyne Gould Corporation building after the Christchurch February earthquake. Tony McCormick who work in the PricewaterhouseCoopers building at the time of the February 22, 2011 Christchurch earthquake and finds himself helping out in that attempt.

column8: Miracle under rubble; 'Oh my God, you are alive'
column9: Describes the time leading up to, during and a short time after the February 22, 2011 Christchurch earthquake by some of those who worked in the Canterbury Television building.

column8: Paraplegic quake surviviors' lives tougher to rebuild
column9: Paraplegic quake surviviors' lives tougher to rebuild

Visits Christchurch a year after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake to report on the progress of the recovery effort. Talks to digger driver Craig Bugden about his work to demolish about 100 homes over the past year. Speaks to business administrator Diane Hale-Fielding, one of the few remaining residents in the suburb of Pacific Park, Bexley, about her experiences of the 4 Sep 2010  and the 22 Feb 2011 earthquakes. Presents his impressions of the desolation of the central business district. Seeks comment from Warwick Isaacs and Roger Sutton of the Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (CERA), landscape architect Di Lucas and Christchurch Central City Business Association manager Paul Lonsdale about opportunities presented by the rebuilding process. Talks to chef Karl Lau about the uncertainty he faces with his bed and breakfast establishment.

column8: Survivors' perspective of Feb 22 quake poignant; Dark online elements of plot fail to quite hit spot
column9: Survivors' perspective of Feb 22 quake poignant; Dark online elements of plot fail to quite hit spot

column8: It was a miracle : survivor; Selfless actions saved 4 lives; [Christchurch - a year on]
column9: Talks to the mother who was trapped after the CTV building collapsed in the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake about her 'miracle' rescue. Speaks to her rescuer, who she nominated for a Christchurch Earthquake Award for his valour, about rescuing her and three other people.

column8: Saved woman's identity mystery to rescuer; [Christchurch - a year on]
column9: Speaks to the North Canterbury contractor who rescued a woman from the CTV building after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Recounts how he nearly lost his own life when the earthquake struck while he was working on the Trinity Presbyterian Church, which had been damaged in the 4 Sep 2010 earthquake.

column8: We'll close more buildings, say quake engineers
column9: Reports building engineers are being more cautious in their inspection of damaged buildings in Christchurch in the light of information coming out of the royal commission. Comments on the time frame within which the engineers are having to make decisions about a building's structural integrity and the implications of being very conservative on the Christchurch rebuild.

column8: Double acts in the city; CEO convinced city needs him
column9: Looks back on the city's recent series of leadership partnerships involving Christchurch City Council (CCC) mayors and their chief executive officers (CEOs), including Vicki Buck and Mike Richardson through the 1990s, Garry Moore and Lesley McTurk through most of the 2000s, and the current team of Bob Parker and Tony Marryatt. Talks about the current row over the CCC leadership. Speaks to CCC CEO Tony Marryatt about the ongoing agitation against his reappointment.

column8: Rate of departure abates; Life becomes normal but effects are lasting; Family ties convince couple to stay; [Christchurch - a year on]
column9: Examines life in the city one year after the devastating earthquake on 22 Feb 2011. Provides statistics showing that the rate of departure from the city has slowed. Talks to two families about their respective decisions to leave and remain in Christchurch.

column8: City's rebirth begins; Building foundations over top : developer
column9: Reports on why few commercial landowners are rebuilding in the city at present. Speaks to a number landowners, including developer Richard Diver, preschool teacher Joanna Beadle, Ferry Oak Properties Richard Peebles, and Edgeware SuperValue owner Stephen Anderson, about their frustrations and plans, and to Christchurch City Council earthquake building services manager Ethan Stetson about why some commercial building consents have been delayed. Talks to Consortium Construction foreman Shayne Chilton and Ferry Oak Properties developer Richard Peebles about the heavily strengthened and reinforced foundations for the new building on the corner of Moorhouse Avenue and Montreal Street.

column8: Canterbury quake : one year on; My year of living warily
column9: Writes of life in post-earthquake Christchurch and Sumner and the emotional aspects of earthquake recovery. Looks at some of the events and government processes that have become part of the 'anger and depression' recovery stage. Discusses the importance of recognising the gains along with the pains. Includes part of a timeline of events.

column8: Canterbury quake : one year on; Staying alive
column9: Meets manager James Meharry and partner Karyn South, owners of the radio station RDU98.5FM in Christchurch. Talks about their experiences in the Feb 2011 earthquake and how they turned a horse truck into a mobile radio station and got their business back up and running. Includes part of a timeline of events.

column8: Canterbury quake : one year on; 'Every day is tough'
column9: Talks to David and Jeanette Beaumont, who lost their adopted son Matt when the CTV building collapsed, about their last memories of him. Includes part of a timeline of events.

column8: Canterbury quake : one year on; 'Ear to the ground'
column9: Describes the sound that accompanied the Christchurch earthquakes and the above-ground results of the shockwaves colliding. Explains what Christchurch sounds like now with the various rebuilding work that is being done. Includes part of a timeline of events.

column8: Earthquake stress a factor in murder, court told
column9: Earthquake stress a factor in murder, court told

column8: Sense of disbelief in wake of night-time devastation; Shaky sense of disbelief
column9: Reports on her tour of the city in the aftermath of the destructive earthquake in Canterbury on 4 Sep 2010. Talks to local residents and family members about their experiences.

column8: Brace yourselves, Wellington; High time for Wellingtonians to brace themselves
column9: Reminds that the capital city is considered overdue for a large earthquake, explaining the three fault lines that lie below it. Presents risk modelling estimates, and a possible scenario, for an earthquake of the magnitude that struck Christchurch. Describes the Wellington Earthquake National Initial Response Plan and illustrates the estimated time taken for recovery of services. Details damage caused by the 1942 earthquake centred over Masterton. Alludes to the general unpreparedness of city residents.

column8: When will it stop?; Canterbury tales; 'If I'm going to die I want to die with Jo'
column9: Traces the week after the Canterbury earthquake for Christchurch residents. Talks to a number of people about their experiences. Provides a graph to illustrate the number of aftershocks that hit the region in the week. Presents columnist Paul Holmes' personal narrative about his visit to Christchurch after the quake, and Christchurch mayor Bob Parker's experience.

Looks at how NZ's two main television networks, TVNZ and TV3, covered the Canterbury earthquake. Talks to TV3's Mark Jennings, long-time television journalist Janet Wilson, and journalism professor Jim Tully for their opinions about the coverage.

Looks at the chances of another magnitude 7 or more earthquake hitting NZ after the Canterbury earthquake and the possibility of predicting earthquakes. Touches on preparing for a big earthquake for the public and local authorities. Provides a map showing 10 years of shallow earthquakes in NZ.
Presents the author's personal experience of the Canterbury earthquake.

Recalls the aftermath of the 1968 Inangahua earthquake and talks to some of the survivors who also experienced the Canterbury earthquake (4 September 2010). Touches on the Modified Mercalli (MM) intensity scale and how it has been applied to major NZ earthquakes.
Reports on how news of the earthquake in Canterbury was reported in NZ and throughout the world via text messages, blogs, Internet news sites and other social networking media.

column8: The day of reckoning; Amazing response
column9: Reflects on the events of the past week since the magnitude 7.1 earthquake struck the region at 4.35 am on Saturday, 4 Sep 2010. Comments on the terror of the event and the multiple aftershocks, and the miracle that no one was killed and very few people were seriously injured despite the severity of the quake. Praises the rapid response of the population and emergency services and the relatively quick recovery of infrastructure and most businesses. Talks to people about how they are coping in the aftermath of the event, and describes the damage to homes and some historic buildings. Touches on future priorities for the region.

Reports on the psychological effects of the 4 Sep earthquake for residents of the region, and the adjustments they will need to make in the coming weeks and months to cope with the aftermath. Talks to several psychologists and to residents Marge Straw and Peter Straw, to Bishop of Christchurch Victoria Matthews and Burwood-Pegasus community board chairman David East.

column8: Already struggling, some businesses won't survive
column9: Concentrates on the economic impact of the 4 Sep 2010 earthquake on the business community, particularly on the Christchurch central business district. Informs that there may be some economic gains in the medium term in the construction and related industries.
Talks to Christian Livingstone of the rock quartet about their decision to continue with their upcoming concert despite the recent earthquake, AL's Bar, Christchurch, 16 Sep 2010.

Talks to the film aficionado and distributor about building his independent cinema business in Christchurch, his tussles with the cinema chain monopolies, and censorship. Reveals who sewed the arthouse theatres' waterfall curtains, affirms the high and low brow tastes of his shows, and mentions his home theatrette. Details the earthquake damage sustained by movie theatres in Christchurch.

column8: Rebuilding answers lie in the soil
column9: Explores the phenomenon of liquefaction. Examines earthquake-damaged houses in Kaiapoi, and a subdivision in Bexley wetlands originally opposed by the Christchurch City Council, which were affected by liquefying soil. Notes international interest by scientists and geotechnical engineers in the effects of the process. Talks to specialists about the susceptibility of soft soil areas, the contribution of this year's high water table, and the success of soil compaction techniques carried out at the new Pegasus Town near Woodend.

Looks at the likely impact of the Canterbury earthquake on the NZ economy and overall Gross Domestic Product (GDP) by using the economic situation in Chile after a magnitude 8.8 earthquake struck the southwest of that country on 27 February 2010.

Examines the nature of the relationship between the two largest cities in the South Island, taking into account the aftermath of the 4 Sep 2010 earthquake in Christchurch. Seeks views of health professionals, city councillors, civil defence authorities and businesspeople about the often unseen business, social and other interactions between the two cities.

Talks to residents of various Christchurch suburbs, including Brooklands, about the aftermath of the Canterbury earthquake. Briefly discusses using drama as therapy for children traumatised by the earthquake. Portrays the earthquake through the viewpoint of two young girls.
